13/09/2025 This was a complex and persistent complaint. A full response was issued last week, and the complaint file has now been closed. Please refer to PRM comments for further detail and context regarding the handling and resolution of this case.
29/09/2025 Complaint Casework Nearing Completion. Progress has continued since the last update, with close collaboration across teams to support a thorough review and draft the response letter. We are now undertaking final checks to ensure the response is accurate, balanced in tone, and reflects NHS complaint standards - being fair, open, evidence-based, and focused on learning. Once these checks are complete and CDG confirms the content, the response will be submitted to Directors of Nursing Jo Basketfield and Julie Tracey for final approval and sign-off.

column21:
Daughter raises concerns regarding neglect during admission prior to father's passing unable to write sooner due to the mental impact the situation had on family . Specific Areas Requiring Investigation:
1. The Never Event and breach of Duty of Candour
2. Staffing levels and impact on patient care
3. Implementation of outdated COVID-19 protocols
4. DNR discussion and lack of proper capacity assessment
5. Communication breakdown between consultants
6. Palliative care delays and inadequacies
7. Training deficiencies in basic care procedures
8. Failure to provide family support as per hospital policy
9. Undignified management of palliative patients

column21:
Had major surgery on sarcoma on 06/12, discharged on 16/12 at around 8pm – no porter was called, patient was made to walk from her room on ward all the way to the exit of the hospital.
Patient was discharged without any paperwork, pain relief medication and blood thinners.
Patient was discharged with the same wound dressing post op.
Staples were supposed to be removed 10 days after operation, this did not happen and they were removed on 28th/29th after going to the doctors about it.

column6: Helen Simms, Patient Services Team (Complaints & PALS), , Helen.Simms@uhb.nhs.uk
column12: Accident & Emergency QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column17: Clinical Treatment, Clinical Treatment, Clinical Treatment
column18: Diagnosis - Incorrect/missed, Delay or failure in ordering tests, Diagnosis - Delay/Failure
column21:
Inadequate care of wife in ED. Despite presenting with acute neurological symptoms suggestive of an acute attack of Multiple Sclerosis (MS), she was discharged without appropriate investigation, diagnosis, or follow-up care. This negligence caused significant stress, suffering, and a delay in essential treatment. The doctor dismissed concerns and instead diagnosed:
1. Carpal Tunnel Syndrome as the explanation for her hand symptoms.
2. Low Vitamin D levels for her other symptoms, despite her Vitamin D levels being normal during her pregnancy and recent tests.
Discharged without:
• A referral to a neurologist.
• An urgent MRI or any imaging.
• Any diagnostic blood tests.
• A treatment plan or follow-up care.

column21:
Patient emailed with full summary of complaint re poor care and treatment since 2018 from Consultant at  QEHB; in particular misdiagnosis, lack of proper diagnostic action and treatment, continuous delays and dismissive behaviour by Consultant; Patient needs immediate diagnosis and surgical intervention for tumours.  Patient had also contacted PALS (Ref PALS-122) who had arranged for the transfer of her care, which Patient was happy with, but she was also advised by Ombudsman to contact ICB, who redirected her to Complaints so that the overall issues can be investigated in a formal capacity.
NB:  Patient does not speak English and requires an interpreter if contacted by phone; if her Daughter is available she will do this.

Logged on Radar, launched to Officer and sent acknowledgement.
NB:  Patient did ask if when calling a translator could be provided should Daughter not be available; I explained that most of the communication would be via email/letter, but that I would put a  note regarding the interpreter request on the case file.

column21: Patient  was booked in for a cat 3 c-section on the 5th of October to deliver child. Very disappointed and upset with the care received. Before  c-section she had beg the consultant and doctors in triage to take her seriously with concerns due to  daughter having reduced movements. Came into triage numerous times and was put on a monitor for 20 minutes and told to leave. Had a minor car crash on the 28th of September and attended triage as baby had not moved.  Concerns post op placenta not entirely removed discharge and ended up at anther hospital admitted to ITU had 700mls if placental left  - did not see her baby for 10 days told by other hospital she received negligent care from c-section - Impacted on mental health diagnosed with PTSD

column21: Patient's mother says her son has been on Ward 16 since October 2024. She says she was told that hospital staff were not acting legally as patient was not sectioned and not under a DOLS at the time.  Patient was initially on a 72-hour hold beginning of October 2024 but that ran out.  Throughout the months of October and November, she says that patient was being restrained and sedated.  The last time this happened was on 1 December 2024.

column12: Accident & Emergency QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
a)	Why when they attended, did nobody speak to him to get a history for his wife = he said nobody spoke to them at all and no x-ray was done.  Why was no x-ray carried out?
b)	Complaint  had asked for his wife to be resuscitated = was this carried out as he is concerned that after leaving the hospital, he was called 20 minutes later to return.
c)	Should a cardiac doctor have reviewed his wife?  If not, why not. If they should have, why was this not done?
d)	Complainant would like confirmation of what his wife died from. He was told "something in the lung" but would like full clarity and information.
e)	Doesn't understand how we said that she had virus as she did not have this at home. 
f)	RE: Physio issue: Patient cannot recall exact date but was before COVID pandemic.  Patient was discharged from ward who looked after her in east wing.  When being discharged, they were told that somebody would call them within 24-48 hours for an appointment to attend the house and carry out physio.  He is adamant that he was told that this would be somebody from the QE hospital – why did this not take place, resulting in him having to bring her back into the hospital. 

Contact n. 07827 370471.
Email : philrj1954@sky.com (However would prefer us to communicate via telephone or letter as he does not check his emails often).

column6: Jimmy Lang, Patient Services Team (Complaints & PALS), , Jimmy.Lang@uhb.nhs.uk
column12: Specialty - Upper GI Surgery (Incl Sarcoma) QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21:
Writing complaint to get closure on father's death. Father was diagnosed with Oesophagus cancer. His consultant Upper GI surgeon, aimed at a cure by arranging chemotherapy followed by surgery. His operation took place on 17th January 2024 at Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham for minimally invasive Oesophagectomy but this unfortunately led to serious complications, resulting with him going on life support in ICU. However, after being there for over 3 months and despite all odds he was eventually discharged and came home on 20th April 2024 to continue is recovery.Therefore as a grieving family with unanswered questions
1. How did the cancer spread when we had been told it had all been removed?
2. How did the cancer go undetected after being in the QE Hospital for over 3 months?
3. Was the cancer missed on previous scans whilst at QE hospital between 17 January - 20 April?
4. Should we have received any information or follow up communication from the medical professional team who my father was under explaining how or why this happened? Or is it not their responsibility once their patient has died?

column12: Haematology & Oncology Day Unit SH (Solihull Hospital Site)
column21: wife raises several concerns with regards to her husbands treatement under oncology - discharge papers have incorrect date and information - delay in scans - In conclusion,  family feel patient was let down significantly from the get go is an understatement.  Patient's tests prior to treatment starting all showed dramatic changes, why was his treatment plan not changed / discussed further? Why didn't you consult with him to explain the rapid progression and the associated complications this may cause?  He should have been given a choice as to continue as planned or re assess?  The quality of life he endured from October to 6th December is inhumane in my humble opinion.

column21: No nursing handover had been given from ward 12 at Solihull to ward staff and no confirmation from ward that a bed was available for them to send patient. Patient is MRSA positive and requires a sideroom. Contacted staff nurse on ward 12 and she was told that handover had been given the previous day and bed was available. Contacted Matron for ward 37 and CSM, patient to stay on ward 37 and wait until patient was discharged in 5.2 for sideroom 3 to be transferred and Solihull patient to use. Patient in 5.2 discharged 2 hours later at 18:10 hrs and Solhull patient waited in visitors room. Contacted SAU sister to place patient on admissions board to be reviewed by Urology team for clerking.

column12: Ward 24 GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column21: FLR frustrating and somewhat insulting with the time it has taken to receive response, and the findings detailed which fail to provide with any assurance of a full investigation. Complaint was raised on the 31st of October 2024, the letter starts by confirming my complaint was received on the 2nd of October 2024 for his admission from the 7th – 22nd October. The letter also acknowledges fathers' vulnerabilities and complex health condition although the treatment you claim to have provided failed to meet his basic needs, yet you remain "Sorry we felt that way" rather than a simple apology for the way in which he was treated and any acknowledgement of the failings. This is not acceptable.

column12: Specialty - Oncology (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21: Pt. had an appointment on 13/06/24 with Dr  told she would be booked for an urgent scan within two weeks.  No appointment received. She went to have bloods done and asked receptionist in Oncology department if she should have received an appointment for a scan by then.  Her next appointment with the consultant was cancelled but she had still not received a date for a scan. Pt contacted Dr  by phone who told her that she requested the scan but, on checking the system, it looked as if someone cancelled it and it had not been rebooked. She has since had a scan but wanted to know who and why the request was cancelled.  .

column12: Accident & Emergency BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21: Disturbing experience at BHH ED and the actions of the staff encountered at reception, whose choices directly contributed to unreasonable delays in  receiving medical attention. reception asked to see ID, provided government-issued digital ID she refused it on the grounds that she can't accept a picture. Explained that this is a government app (and not a picture) where the ID is maintained live. For your purposes, the app-based ID  was presenting can be likened to the recently digitised UKVI visas, like the BRP, which I understand is the only valid ID many BRP holders will have in the UK once their physical cards expire. Hannocke refused that ID too, saying she needs a physical ID that she can scan and send to her admin team to check how I will be billed. The fact that she would scan and digitise the physical ID anyway confused me, and receptionist dismissed any follow-up questions, maintaining that she would not accept anything but a physical ID.  For an hour, I waited in A&E with an aggravating injury, without painkillers or medical attention, while my friends fetched my ID

column12: Ward 02 BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21: Son contacted PALS on 28/01/25 following advice from mother's carers. Concerns relate to her discharge from BHH W2 on 02/12/24.  Son says that his mother was prescribed 1000mg Levetiracetam.  Son says this is negligent ("a huge dose").  He wants to know who and why a doctor prescribed this. He explained that his mother is constantly drowsy and says the medication is not fit for her. He wants to stop the medication entirely.  We discussed during a telephone call on 05/02/2025 at 14.20 that he should link in with her mother's GP. On reviewing Clinical Portal, I can see GP has received advice and guidance.

column12: Ward 15 GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column21: Patient had been recovering on Ward 17 at GHH for approximately 6 weeks. He was transferred to Ward 15 on 05/02/25.  He got out of bed himself to go and walk to the toilet during the evening. He had limited mobility and leaned on a bed close by. The bed moved quickly, and he fell and hit his head.  Nursing staff informed wige shortly after the incident and apologised. She says she was told that the bed's brakes were not on at the time.  She says that three nurses picked him up off the floor and says they knew they were not allowed to do this until he was reviewed by a doctor.

column12: Ward 05 GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column21: Due to the size of the cyst, it was advised that this would need to be removed. This was a minor operation and only should have taken a couple of hours. Upon waking from my procedure, learnt that it was not as straight forward as expected as a result of my C Section operation. The consultant found that my bowels were connected to my pelvis, and placed a lot higher than they should be situated. Extensive adhesions were found in my abdominal and a piece of fat bad tissue, was found from my belly button down to my C Section scar. I have attached the pictures post my op and my consultant letters for your information and evidence.

column17: Admissions, Discharges, and Transfers (excluding delayed discharge due to absence of care package)
column21:
Inadequate care in ED - patient not provided with a bed husband in alot of pain staff advised they had no beds and that he would need to go home. Wife telephoned the department to explain what had happened. She says she was told nothing has been recorded on the system. She says that when she was on the phone to her husband she could hear a lot of commotion. She says she was concerned so called the police who said they would do welfare check.  Patient put into a taxi and sent home.
Patient returned to the department the following day for the MRI.  His wife says she brought him in by car with the help of another family member. She chased for the results of the MRI a few days later and says he was classed an inpatient and she says this is incorrect.  She confirmed that the results have been sent to her husband's GP. They have been told the GP has put in an urgent referral for her husband to be seen at the QE with the spinal team.   The police crime reference number is 00026703022025

column12: Radiotherapy QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21: Patient has brain tumour which was operated on at Stoke University hospital on 9/12/24. She was transferred to the QE for combined chemotherapy and radiotherapy.  Radiotherapy started on 03/02/25 and was going well until Friday 07/02/25.  Once her radiotherapy finished at 3pm that day, the Radiotherapy opened the door. Husand was sat outside the room and he heard a scream He got up and saw that his wife had fallen off the table.  Husband says there was only one Radiographer present who helped his wife sit up.  He says she banged her head and hip during the fall.  Medics rushed to her and his wife was in pain. Subsequently discovered that she has broken her hip and had surgery on 08/02/25.  She has had to omit radiotherapy today and hopes to resume tomorrow

column12: Acute Medical Unit (AMU) QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21:
serious concerns about the care of patient before her passing on 8th February 2025. Family need answers regarding the circumstances leading to her death, as they believe there were significant failings in her treatment.
1. Why was the feeding plan ignored? Who made the decision to administer 100ml instead of 30ml?
2. Why was no biopsy ever performed on the pancreatic tumour to confirm its nature, despite clear evidence of growth?
3. Why was no abdominal scan done in hospital, despite her documented history?

column12: Main Outpatients Department QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21:
Follow up - Doesn't understand why Dr was alone during initial consultation and why a nurse was present as is usual – feels this was deliberate so that there were no witnesses to his alleged poor behaviour and comments.
Adamant that no telephone calls were attempted to him on either landline or mobile – no record of missed calls.
States that Dr greeted him with "what are you doing here" and "you've been referred with tummy pains". Believes the referral letter and detailed contained within were completely ignored.
Feels UHB staff deliberately looked at imaging from 2015 rather than that taken in 2022 which evidenced the cause of his symptoms
Felt completely dismissed, says he was told "not worried about that" when questioning the biloma. Upset at being dismissed and being told he had "tummy pain". Says he asked to be shown his UHB scan from 2024 but was denied.

ZK  23/05/2025 14:50 - Letter template update with further concerns and circulated to Jenn ifer Todd, Skhbir Rayatt, Shivram Singh, George Filobbos, Alli Page and Gail Moore.

ZK 20/05/2025 14:19 -Email from complainant stating he wishes to add the following concern - "I'd also like to know why Dr Singh told the pals team that he had explained to me why the second tumour was not removed although it's clear to see on scan, and that I was happy with his explanation even though no such explanation was giving by him and I'm certainly not happy and never told him I was happy with any explanation, that wasn't given in first place".

ZK 20/05/2025 11:50 - Letter populated and complaint distributed to Jess Hitchings, Shivram Singh, George Filobbos, Sukhbir Rayatt, Mohammed Maher, Alli Page, Gali Moore and Am Lidhar.

ZK 20/05/2025 11:31 - Email to complainant detailing concerns put forward to the team. I have asked for him to confirm that these are correct follwoing our tel conversation.

ZK 16:58 19/05/2025 - I placed a call to complainant at 16:58 on 19/05/2025. He advised that he has is not happy and feels that it is all a cover up. He advised Dr Mohammed told hiom to log it as a complaint because both tumours were evident from the scans and can't understand how it was missed during the initial operation. He advised when he came in for his second operation whilst he was preparing for theatre on the ward a Dr came (south african) to him and tried to intimdate him by saying we heard you're not happy with how the surgery went too which he replied no, i am not because you didn't remove it all so i have had to come back in again for a second surgery. To which dr replied "well what do you know, you aren't a doctor". Whilst he was being administered anathesia in theatre he said Dr Singh came in and said "i heard you are not happy with the surgery to which you saod i am just going into surgery, the previous dr got his back up and now he felt Dr Singh was trying to explain the reason for why the tumopur was missed. Richard asked him to leave and said this nit the time nor the place. I have advised Richard that this case was assigned to me recently and i will try and get a quick turn around for him but it may breach the due date. He is happy with this. He advises he has already had a meeting so will opt for a written response and follwoing this he will go to the Ombudsman if he still reminas unhappy. He advises that oif it was missed iin error then for staff to be truthful and own up to their mistake but he feel that through conversations with everyone their stories keep changing which has led him to belive that something is being covered up.

column12: Specialty - Critical Care BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21:
Patient's partner called to log formal complaint regarding incident that occurred on 15th June 23 patient was taken to BHH with anti freeze poisoning, had a tracheostomy on 22nd June and was admitted in ITU.
Patient's partner had been going to visit everyday, around a week after surgery when she went to visit she noticed there was bleeding around the tracheostomy. She raised her concerned with a few nurses/ staff on ward who said they would monitor the bleeding.
14 hours later – in the early hours of 30th -she received a call from the hospital and was told patient had a haemorrhage- cardiac arrest which has led to severe brain damage. Doctors advised the haemorrhage was caused by the poisoning – but after thinking it through more and speaking to other people she believes something is not right and it is connected to the bleeding.

column12: Accident & Emergency QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21:
Concerns relate to the patient's attendance at QE ED on 11/02/25 which are detailed in the email below. Discussion with daughter-in-law and son on 25/02/25 and they want an investigation.  The primary issue is that patient was left in ED for so long (approximately 40 hours) on an inappropriate mattress.  Patient has subsequently developed a pressure sore on her sacrum. Tissue Viability Nurses have assessed her on Ward 518 – her care home say she did not have this before she left for ED.  Other concerns such as inadequate food in the department and communication issues with staff – especially (unnamed) staff member who said she had to "watch her back because of attacks by syringes".  

Patient and family are satisfied with her current care on Ward 518.

ZK 10/06/2025 12:53 - Placed a call to patients mother today and informed them of the breach and advised we are loooking to streamline theor daughters care so that the metabolic team are involved for all her presentations to the hospital. She thanked me and advised her daughter has been in hospital from Friday 6 June 2025.

ZK 10/06/2025 12:35 - Returned call from Ciaran Basketfield. He advised that because the metabolic team were never informed of the patients presenmtation he feels they cannot answer any of the concerns but rather Ciran will liaise withh colleagues to determine of a clear pathway can be developed tailored for the patient and then come back to me.

ZK 09/06/2025 17:11 - Responded to Barry Boland regarding email dated 10 March 25.

ZK 09/06/2025 14:54 - Comments from Barry Boland.

ZK 10/06/2025 11:20 - Urgent request for comments from metabolic team sent to Ciaran Basketfield. I also tried to call him at 11:20am but there was no answer.

ZK 05/06/2025 18:03 - Placed a call to patients father today. I explained that we may breach the due date for him to reciev his response letter as we are still waiting on comments from one dr. I explained i am off on annual leave tomorrow but i have sent an email for the comments to be sent to me by tomorrow so we can aim to get it to him before it breaches. I explained my senior leadership are cc'd in the email and will support in trying to get this signed off tomorrow. He expressed that he wishes for the metabolic team to be more involved in his daugjhter's care from when she enters the ED department to when she is dicscharged. I asked how he feels the metabolic team could assist and expressed for them to ensure timely implentation of his daughter's medical emergewncy care plan.  i.e have her bloodworks been done, has her IV medication been made up and has she been cannulated. He expressed the ED team always struggle to cannulate her and this delays her treatment. He also mentioned that her care at the children's hospital was very good but feels since her transition to QEHB there seems to be a catalogue of errors. He expressed the metabolic team in Manchester are very good and asks if the team here are willing to liaise with them to gain a wider understanding of the steps that need to be taken when his daughter has a crisis. I explained i will speak with leadership and vunerablilites next week to determine of we there is anything further we can offer to tighten and streamline the care plan some more. He thanked me and said he would like for me to call him back next week.

column23:
Escalation and Management of Complaint Behaviour:

This complaint has become increasingly complex since it was first received. Persistent contact with services, including episodes of aggressive behaviour, has presented ongoing challenges in engaging constructively with the patient.

Staff are advised to log any concerning incidents onto RADAR, particularly where further contact involves aggressive or abusive behaviour. In line with our communication protocol, staff should issue up to 3 clear warnings during any interaction where behaviour is inappropriate or hostile. 

If the behaviour continues despite these warnings, the call may be terminated in accordance with Trust policy.

This approach is intended to protect staff wellbeing while ensuring that all patients are treated fairly and respectfully. Please remain vigilant and document any incidents thoroughly.

column12: Main Outpatients Department SH (Solihull Hospital Site)
column19: Missed Deadline – Delay with Medical comments
column21:
Patient had a clinic appointment on 25/03/25 where they also spoke about his concerns. He has been diagnosed with cancer (scale 6) 
On contacting him following the clinic appointment he has advised he wishes to raise a formal complaint. He feels the delays in responding to his high PSA results and lack of treatment for prostatitis have meant his cancer has grown. He has asked for his prostate to be removed and hope it is not too late to have stopped the cancer spreading. He has a 7year old son and does not want to die

He is unsure of the dates of his bloods etc but advises he had a blood test which saw his PSA raised and the consultant said he would do another blood test and if it was raised again he would refer him to the appropriate consultant. The second set of bloods were raised but there was no referral and later a third set of bloods was taken which again were raised and still no referral.  The patient contacted his GP who was the person who pushed for action on his high PSA. He feels Mr Natalwala was only ever interested in his bladder and trying different medications for that than dealing with his prostate. 


1. Why did the consultant treat him this way? The patient feels it was race related.
2. Why were the high PSA blood results ignored, and he was not referred for further investigation?
3.After the patients first biopsy he should have had a follow up scan and he did not, why not?
4. Why didn't they treat him for his prostatitis?

column12: Specialty - Surgical Assessment Unit (SAU) BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
Poor experiences at Heartlands hospital -Cannulas not inserted correctly 4 times causing pain. Enema not carried out well and there's a red patch in my stoma and it wasn't even offered in my rectum to remove anything even though this was suggested to me in first triage with doctors.
Cannula not removed until after I was having a panic attack and no support with my heart palpitations other than blood pressure test. Not telephoned with results earlier in the day on 5th March even though they was aware I was starving myself until I knew the results and then I became nauseated, dizzy and developed a serious migraine. I also have been recovering from multiple deficiencies and wasn't taken any oral supplements. 
No IV supplements offered nor pain relief. No advice given around supplements, pain relief, or food provoking pain so there's no diagnosis or advice given. Or treatment so I'll be contacting my GP to try constipation and IBS treatment as Buscopan not working.

17/06/25- Call received from complainant advising that he feels point 7 of his complaint has not been addressed/misinterpreted.  He has advised that he anticipates Dr Moore was the clinician who saw his mother in the morning however, his concern related to the clinician who reviewed his mother's knee in the afternoon and deeming that her knee was okay and she would be fit for discharge. After the complainant requested that this be reflected in the notes he raised this with the nurse for a second opinion who asked two registrars to review the patient who drained fluid and the patient was admitted for a further week.  Complainant has advised that the concerns relate to this clinician deeming the patient to be okay despite her being in pain and her knee being swollen.

column12: Specialty - Cardiology BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21:
1.	Patient raised a complaint in 2018.  She says the information in the complaint response (see attached point 2) by Dr  is not on her medical records. When she attended a recent Cardiology appointment, the information about the procedure completed by Dr  could not be seen. She believes this should be uploaded to her medical records.  Also regarding the complaint, when her initial enquiry was taken by PALS, I could not find the complaint on datix records. She says this caused her anxiety. I had reassured her that I would make an enquiry (an email inquiry was sent to Complaints) and this was located on the O: drive.  A copy of the letter has been posted to Pt. today. She is not happy that I was not able to locate the response initially. 
2.	 Pt. requested that her pre-op appt of 28/01/25 was rearranged to a F2F appt due to having a speech impairment. IP bookings offered her a F2F appt for 04/03/25 and she accepted this.  KS. had a telephone conversation with Pt.  on 25/02/25 and explained about the pre-op clinics – see attached. On speaking to Mrs Fitter today, she does not accept this explanation and believes a reasonable adjustment should have been made for her to attend a F2F appt at either the QE or Solihull Hospital.

column12: Breast Care QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21:
1.	I did not complain that despite being told in Oct 2021 that my operation (mastectomy and breast reconstruction) was urgent I did not complain when it took until Feb 2022 to have the operation. I received the diagnosis two weeks after my mum died of cancer (and Ive previously lost my dad to cancer) but I understood when doctor said I had good cancer and waited
2.	I did not complain when I was in hospital that my pain relief drip was taken away at 10am and despite ringing the bell numerous times it took until the night shift to come on to receive pain killers (I still remember the lovely night shift nurses name was Rosie and she listened to me cry and gave me pain relief)
3.	I did not complain when I had my first annual mammogram on my other boob in March 2023 and it took until October 2023 to receive letter confirming all was ok (despite numerous calls requesting this) I did not complain when I had my second annual mammogram on 4th April 2024 and it took till end of June 2024 to get letter saying all was OK (3 months seemed better than the previous 6 months
Services are trying to engage with the patient and are attempting to arrange for her to be seen in clinic to discuss concerns and we've had some comments back re the mammogram (see attached correspondence). There is a chance we could have this resolved by the 5 day call, though I feel its important that we now have a written response to these concerns for further learning across the board.

column21: During an OPA on 29/07/24, patient/wife were told about a pulmonary rehabilitation clinic that would have benefitted Pt.  In Sept 2024, there were told the referral for the clinic would be expedited. A further OPA was on 25/11/24.  The clinic letter from this appointment was not received by them at the time. A copy was obtained from their GP.  In this letter it said that a leaflet would be forwarded about a new drug for Pt. – drug named Nintedanib.  This leaflet never arrived and there were not given the opportunity to discuss the new drug.  They have since received the leaflet. They attended an OPA with Dr on 24/02/25.  They raised these issues and Dr Cheng apologised.  She says Dr said they would chase the referral for the rehab clinic but they are not hopeful this will happen. They think this may have benefited Pt. if he was offered the opportunity sooner. She says her husband is breathless and has been suffering.  She thinks he could have been helped sooner.  They have received the clinic letter from Dr Chdated 24/02/25. She says there are a few things wrong in this. In the diagnoses section, on page 2, item 5 – bladder cancer.  'Await further biopsy' is incorrect as this has been completed. On page 5, at the top where it says 'I have advised that they remember to' – she says none of this was discussed during the appointment

column21: medical negligence , lack of care and compassion and untimely intervention of treatment after patient was re-admitted after a failed discharge resulted in his death - delay in treatment - staff attitude  - medication placed in a locker including insulin which needed to be put into a fridge. Staff sittin g watchin tik tok videos at quite a lound volumme no respect and dignity for patient who spent is final day on the ward . Would also like to highlight the fact that not one healthcare professional actually told Pt. that he was dying - that was left to family. Pt. was able to understand and communicate with us right until the last night before he passed away. Where is the duty of candour to your patients and accountability?

column12: Accident & Emergency GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column21:
patient absconded from ED stafff not aware until family called by patient 
1.	We understand nurses are under a lot of pressure, and only human and may snap on the odd occasion, buy someone could of least apologied and checked in on Pt. to make sure she was ok,  as she is 80 years old this year!
2.	 No one noticed Pt. had gone missing for nearly an hour until I arrived and told them, how long would it have been before reported?
3.	No one thought to ring next of kin to see if we knew where she was and technically to update us on the situation/ CCTV findings as she can get a little confused when anxious  and could have got on the wrong  bus, in a car, ran over etc etc,  the list is endless and scary to even think about.  As no one knew at the Hospital until the Doctor rang at 7pm, she was safe and at home!
4.	No one from the hospital or her doctors have even rang her to see if she is ok, as I believe an Echo was also needed and what the X-ray, blood test results were.
5.	Surely, switchboards should know peoples job titles to save time and put through correctly and have some sort of message service to pass on?

column21: Concern regarding the treatment received during  blood test at the Bloods Department of Solihull ..Prior to the procedure, motherexplained to the nurse that daughter has a needle phobia and that this was her first blood test. Despite this, the nurse did not provide any reassurance or take the necessary steps to make my daughter feel more comfortable. Unfortunately, the nurse's approach was rough, and as a result, daughter ended up with a significant bruise on her arm, which lasted for two weeks. She also experienced nausea and light-headedness immediately after the test.

column21:
Daughter wants to know: 
Why did ED make him wait and suffer more for those few days?  She says she understands if the fluid could not be drained at the time, but she feels as if medics should have known he needed to be admitted, treated and seen by a specialist and not discharged home.  She says she thinks medics were ageist by sending him home with pain relief.  During his admission, her father had 3 litres of fluid drained. Daughter has said under no circumstances to contact either her father or mother.  Patient has since received a diagnosis for a terminal condition.

column12: Infectious Diseases Outpatients Clinic BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21:
Family had a meeting with the hospital and were told father was  end of life due to no further treatment available to him. Told referrals to the Gold standard pathway would be made and all the relevant services would be involved.  Patient discharged sent home with no discharge papers no referral was made to any of the professionals were made. Daughter contacted the ward on the Saturday only to find out that he was moved to ward 2 before being discharged. No member of the family was informed about the move. Asked for all the discharge forms to be given to daughter Saturday the 22nd of March and the head nurse said she would make the referrals but two weeks later nothing had been done. How can hospital send a dying man home with no support. 
No Mass form 
No Catheter passport
No catheter bags 
No gold standard path way referral 
Was made. It's shocking how a hospital can treat a person this way.

column19: Missed Deadline – Delay with PR drafting
column20: Out of time complaint difficulty finding information
column21: NHS operation preformed at the Spire Solihull at the time this was when NHS were using private hospitals to help out with waiting list. Had right ovary removed and right fallopian removed as there was a cyst growing around these .  Discharged quickly in total agony as Caesarian scar had been re opened for surgery. Unable to walk and took 3 months off work to recover.Within the last year sent for CT scans on my Stomach area . I was referred to the Gynaecologist at Solihull Hospital who has confirmed have badly scarred tissue damage in that area resulting from this Operation.  Also have Varicose veins in the right hand side pelvic area.

column21: Long wait endure in ED - temporary cast applied which was set in the wrong poisition. column12: Accident & Emergency BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21: Concerns regarding the circumstances around my father's (Alan Keen) death at Heartlands hospital on the morning of Friday 28th March 2025. Triaged within minutes of arrival to Heartlands Hospital but the doctor determined that his condition was serious but not priority. They were happy to wait until morning to do further ECGs, a CT scan, etc. The doctor was firm with him that getting out of bed should not happen until further notice, if he needed the toilet "we will bring it to you.  When son arrived at the hospital at 8:30 found him unconscious in a toilet with 2 nurses trying to revive him. They stated they had come to find him as he had been gone awhile. I supported them in trying to wake him and move him off the toilet and onto the floor, the alarm was then raised and the crash team came to try and revive him. Manual CPR was attempted for approximately 5 minutes in the toilet ending around 8:40, he was then transferred to resus and declared dead at 9:15.
column22: Case closed - 27.05.25

column12: Specialty - Acute and Short Stay Medicine BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21: Patient passed away unexpectedly in Heartland's hospital on Friday 2nd August 2024.Daughter not happy that patient was moved from ward to ward. What happens to the poor patients who are alone and have no family or friends around them? lack of communication between wards happened? did Pt. actually have the blood thinning injection administered on the 31st July as the nurse had stated. Mom passed away suddenly and unexpectedly at around 3.10pm that afternoon.  Fortunately, I was with her. A post-mortem was carried out and it was confirmed my Mom's cause of death was a ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm.

column12: Ward 09 GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
Concerns over the treatment of my elderly father who is currently in Good Hope Hospital. Care recieved was extremely below standard and subsequently put him at risk. He was moved from AMU to ward 11 in a bed where he was then removed from the bed and put in a chair in the middle of bay. With no blankets or dignity and to my knowledge was not given any medication or antibiotics. Who made the decision to take his bed away and deemed him 'fit to sit' given the previous 24-48 hours? Ultimately, my main concerns are :
1. Why was the decision made to remove him from a bed when this was clearly putting him at risk due to how poorly he was?
2. Why were no observations done whilst he was detiorating and what times were his antibiotics given? Were any observations done in the time between leaving AMU first thing that morning up until getting a bed at 3pm?
3. Why are unwell patients left uncomfortable with no dignity in the middle of wards just to support 'bed flow'?
4. Whilst in ward 11 but with no bed allocation and not showing on the ward's system who was responsible for his welfare and safety?

Deceased Patient's Daughter initially contacted PALS for help prior to her Father's death in January 2025, but has not received a response since that time.  Complaint is primarily regarding failed discharge from Neurology QEHB following treatment with a subsequent admission to Russells Hall Hospital where Patient passed away; Complainant and Russells Hall was unable to make urgent contact with Neurology at that time with regards to her Father's previous treatment and medication.  Complainant also wishes to complain about lack of help and response from PALS.  
NB:  First email to Complaints was 03.04, which was referred to PALS for further info and a further chase from Complainant was sent to HED Office on 14.04.25.

Complaint regarding the serious delays and communication failures within the Orthodontics Department, which are now causing significant harm to both patient's treatment outcomes and my mental health. Given the circumstances, requests the following:
1.	Immediate clarification of when I will be seen for my overdue appointment.
2.	A full review of my orthodontic treatment to date, including why it has taken so long to complete.
3.	A clear explanation of why communication and appointment scheduling have failed.
4.	Confirmation of what steps will be taken to prevent a recurrence, for myself and for others.

column20:
Initial timescale will not be met.

Extended timescale needed to complete thorough investigation and respond fully to all issues. Complaint complexity is driving the investigation timeline.
column21: Concerns regarding the care of father,  received during his recent hospital stay at University Hospitals QE Birmingham. Was admitted on March 7, 2025, following a fall and subsequent head injury, and was discharged on April 19, 2025. During his stay, he experienced multiple issues relating to communication, dietary needs, staff coordination, and the overall management of his care. Missing equipment - staff communication  loss of hearing aid unexplained dementia diagnosis - discharge paperwork
column22:
30/11 - Case re-badged to Amerjit - Email to Laura asking for most up to date position in respect of response (AL)
29/09/2025 Complaint Casework Progress Update: Significant progress has been made since the last entry. The draft response letter was shared with CDG on 10 September 2025 for their contributions and agreement. Therapies have confirmed the content, while nursing and medical comments remain outstanding. Escalated to Directors of Nursing and Laura Craddock is leading clinical review with CDG colleagues. See PRM notes for more detail.

15/09/2025 This is a backlog complaint that has grown in complexity and involves multiple admissions. A full review of the complaint and the clinical portal has been completed. A draft response letter has been shared. Therapies have provided suggested amendments, and replies from nursing are still awaited. Darren Clearly is supporting the process by coordinating senior nursing reviews and gathering feedback. See PRM Comments for summary of case handling actions. (Awaiting replies from Sonia McNamara, Stacey Fream, Rachael Goulding, Rachel Green, and Darren Cleary)

14/08/2025 Quick review of comments received show nursing and medical comments still outstanding. Discussed with Matron Rachel Green who has emailed the Ward Manager. Awaiting contact from Ward Manager to discuss complaint, with intention to follow up on Monday.

The complaint review document and timeline have been shared with the group to aid input, ensure accuracy, and strengthen the clinical explanations provided. I apologised that he has not been contacted earlier and advised his complaint has been moved to the drafting stage. He went through all his concenrs from before Covid to when his mothers issues started and the lack of care and follow up recived from the dr's. He advises that all he wants is a treatment plan for his mother. He advised the dr's have not been supportive but rather passive aggressive, lack of empathy and he feels his mother has not been provided with any treatment options due to her age. He fears his mother may have a stroken and die due the delay in tretament. He advised that he will be compiling his mothers medical history along with all the interactions with the dr's and he willl be putting forward his case to the ICB for negligence. he may also go down the legal route if his mother is not given treatment. I provided  my direct contact details to him and advised he can call me should he need any further support. He thanked me for the call, stated it was nice to speak with me.

column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
Patient was referred from City hospital to Mr Ward at QEH 2 years ago.
Patient had surgery in April 2024 but the matter was not resolved.
MRI scan done in August received results in November
Patient was seen by Mr Ward end of December – MRI showed patient still has ongoing issues, suggested fistula which makes it more complicated. 
Mr Ward said he does not think it is a fistula 
Patient does not understand how the MRI is showing one thing and the doctor is saying something else.
MRI is suggesting something more serious, why has this not been reflected in clinical diagnosis.
Patient also mentioned he is listed for operation – wants to know how long till he gets date for surgery.
Patient said he wants a higher resolution MRI to clarify what patient has.
Not happy with delays of treatment – wants to know what plan is going forward

column12: Specialty - Immunology UHB (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21: Pt. had a series of tests completed privately because she felt she did not want to wait for her NHS appointment under immunology. She says she has been diagnosed with MCAS (Mast Cell Activation Syndrome). Private consultation recommended a medication called sodium cromoglicate which would cost her £300 per month. Her GP is unable to help because it is hospital-only prescription.  Outcome of MDT was that there was no evidence of urticaria or clinical symptoms in keeping with mast cell degranulation – this has been diagnosed by a private allergist.  Suggested that if she needs the prescription that she goes back to the private allergist.

On Ward 621 he mothers catheter had burst and a HCA nurse told her daughter that she leaving her shift in 20 minutes and cannot help because it slow everything else down and that after the handover another nurse should support with chnaging the bed sheets. The complainant further waited for someone to help but advises she took pictures of the nurses advising they were not busy and were sat at nursing station talking about their cats.

She advises that her  other last had a CT scan in Jaunary when she was advised the medical team suspected her mother to have cancer. She advises that her mothber is in need of another scan to determine how advanced the cancer is as she is due her surgery in July. She advises the nursing staff on Harborne ward advised that they do not know when the scan will take place. This lack of coommunication from staff has caused the patients daughter considerable stress and she wants to understand the care plan that has been arranged for her mother. I had advised i will arrange for someone from the ward to call her and offer her wsome assurance.

column12: Ward 02 GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
Pt. admitted to Heartlands AE on 20/03/25 after enduring excruciating abdominal pain.Tests confirmed an 18cm ovarian cyst which would require emergency surgical removal. After looking at previous notes, the doctor explained that the cyst was present in 2014 on pregnancy scans at 6cm. Believes the cyst would have also been present during my pregnancy in 2013.  Firstly, why was Pt. never made aware of the cyst? 
Next,why was there never any follow up?routine scans?
This negligence has resulted in having emergency surgery, where left ovary and tube was also removed along with the cyst. Complaint raised with Pals no outcome received - delay in surgery - lack of pain relief

9.	Why was my history of September 2023 and transfusions not taken into account .

column12: Ward 29 (Modular) GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column21:
Patient had colorectal surgery 9 weeks ago in February, thought everything was fine until she had to go to hospital A&E on 22/04 with vomiting, patient had a CT scan and was sent to SAU where she was told by a doctor that 'instead of connecting her bowel to anus they connected it to her vagina.'

Patient was emotional on the phone and said she was told she will need to have another major surgery to correct this.
They also mentioned they have not encountered this before so don't know how they are going to correct this as they may not be enough bowel to join and she may end up with a colostomy bag.

column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
Concerns regarding the actions, or the lack of actions taken by the District
Nursing team looking after my late wife.We would like you to provide us with answers to the following questions:

1. The documentation completed by yourselves, documents Pt preferred
place of death as 'Hospice' indicating she did not wish to die at home. Why wasthis not addressed?
2. Numerous messages were left on the answerphone by both myself and  J of which only a couple were replied to, why did no one respond to our queries of what was happening with the CHC referral?
3. Why was a nurse allowed to attend and complete the CHC paperwork who was not qualified or competent to undertake this task?
4. Why was no CHC referral form submitted to the CHC team, they have confirmed to us they have no record of any referral?

She has written down what she was told and will send me those details via email before the weekend, once I receive those details, I will forward them onto the department to cross ref . I confirmed that the patients name Jacqueline Wood, PID K618907 are correct. I did mention the possible mix up from the coroner – however, I advised we will not be sure until we can cross reference the details she was provided. column12: Specialty - Neurology UHB (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21:
Complaint about the cancellation of awake craniotomy to remove a brain tumour, which was scheduled for 23 May 2025 at Queen Elizabeth Hospital. This surgery followed a diagnosis of a likely high grade glioma in the left side of my brain on 1 May 2025.  would therefore like clear and detailed responses to the following:
1.Who was responsible for arranging the attendance of the neurophysiologist for this procedure and how did this failure occur?
2.Was this managed internally by University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Trust, or was it handled by a third-party provider?
3.What was the financial cost to the Trust of cancelling this operation at such a late stage?
4.What immediate and ongoing support can be offered to help me manage the pain, distress, and anxiety caused by this delay?
5.What is the earliest possible date that my surgery can now be rescheduled, and what assurances can be given that this situation will not be repeated?

column21: Complaint regarding the prolonged delay in diagnosing and treating patient's Slipped Upper Femoral Epiphysis (SUFE), despite repeated visits to three NHS hospitals: Good Hope Hospital, Sir Robert Peel Hospital, and Burton Hospital, between September 2024 and January 2025. Throughout this period, patient experienced persistent and worsening hip and leg pain, significantly limiting her mobility. Despite raising  concerns repeatedly, her symptoms were dismissed as "growing pains" on multiple occasions. No appropriate investigations or referrals were made, allowing her condition to progress unchecked for four months.

•Why it was virtually impossible to get someone to call me back to discuss my mom's health matters when it was clear that she was having difficulty understanding what was going on.
•Why was she discharged without any prior discussions with me, despite repeated requests from Mom and myself.
•What is the plan going forward - i.e when will she be followed up and by whom, and when she can expect to receive any appointments.  Again, it is imperative that we are notified in advance of any upcoming appointments as either son or his wife will need to take time off work to attend with her.

column12: Imaging QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column18: Diagnosis - Delay in acting on test results
column20: Re-opened complaint deadline met
column21:
Follow up complaint has raised questions regarding KUB CT Scan done on 14th June 2023 informed that the reporting of this scan as a simple 3.4cm ovarian cyst was relayed to the BWC as a simple 2.4cm ovarian cyst, apparently attributing to a NINE MONTH referral wait and a subsequent ultrasound scan. This ultrasound highlighted, a complex heterogenous cyst of a concerning size in excess of that reported by QEHB. This precipitated a CA125 blood test and Oncology Consultation the same week, creating a great deal of anxiety and distress for me over the following weeks.

My confidence in the reporting of the KUB scan has been greatly eroded and I am concerned that a more recent KUB CT Scan done on 21st January 2025, may have also been misinterpreted.

After reading your response and your reasoning behind the differential, I would appreciate the opportunity to discuss my KUB CT Scans with a Consultant Radiologist at QEHB, in order to fully understand and resolve this complaint.

column12: Gynaecology Outpatients Department BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column19: Missed Deadline – Delay with Medical comments
column21: Patient is unhappy that she did not receive any information regarding the option to have a GA or of knowing what the procedure entailed. Though she accepts human error she is very angry and upset that it was only when she was having the procedure she was asked if she had taken pain relief and advised she could have opted for a GA. She is disgusted by the lack of communication and with the before and after care, and that no information on the procedure was provided ahead of it. She feels it was all poorly organised. As the patient hadn't been aware of what to expect she had driven herself in and had to dive back home in pain and bleeding. She states the whole thing was a waste of everyone's time. She has been left traumatised by the whole event.

column17: Admissions, Discharges, and Transfers (excluding delayed discharge due to absence of care package)
column21: On the 22nd April the patient was admitted with suspected meningitis. Investigations done and patient discharged on 25th April. Patient readmitted on the 19th May with weight loss and symptoms of black tar stools and vomiting blood. 21st May endoscopy attempted but unable to complete due to blockage and patient discharged.  Within a few hours, the patient was readmitted and admitted to W3. Patient underwent a further endoscopy on 23rd May and discharged the same day.  Patient had a HB of 82.

column12: Ward 20A SH (Solihull Hospital Site)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
Patient had heart failure and was on 3 medications for her heart but during her whole stay none of her heart medication was given to her.
Son was also concerned that they were giving her very high doses of soluble paracetamol – they contain high sodium salt level which wasn't goof for her with her condition. 
Son mentioned he told nurses many times to stop giving her that and also for her to give her heart medication but they did not listen. 
Patient was taken to BHH on 15th March but unfortunately passed away on 17th March with fluid in lungs, pneumonia and heart failure. 

Son wants an investigation as he believes this contributed to mums death.

column12: Accident & Emergency QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21:
recently received copies of records via a Subject Access Request (SAR), and  extremely concerned by the omissions and inconsistencies within the documentation for that visit. The notes for 22nd April state:
While these details are factually correct, key clinical actions and observations are missing, specifically:
1. A pregnancy test was carried out during this visit and confirmed to be positive. The clinician physically showed me the two lines on the test result.
2. A dipstick urine test was also performed. The clinician told me I had nitrates and blood in my urine and advised me that I had a UTI, that had been "festering".

3. I was prescribed Nitrofurantoin antibiotics during this same visit. I collected the medication from my pharmacy on the same day. I have since spoken to the pharmacy, who have provided a record of this prescription, confirming it came from the hospital on 22nd April 2025.
4. I raised the possibility of an ectopic pregnancy during the consultation. I told the clinician that my symptoms were in my womb, and this was the only explanation I could think of. She asked me to lie down, examined my abdomen, and reassured me that because the pain was central rather than one-sided, I should not worry about an ectopic pregnancy.
None of these significant interactions are recorded in my notes for that date.

column12: Ward 12 GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column17: Admissions, Discharges, and Transfers (excluding delayed discharge due to absence of care package)
column21:
Complaint regarding the unacceptable, unsafe, and unprofessional handling of 94-year-old grandmother's care and discharge from Good Hope Hospital, where she was an inpatient during 11th April 2025 to 3rd May 2025.

 I am formally requesting a full investigation into:
 The failure to consult or inform the next of kin prior to discharge decisions.
 The repeated breakdown of communication internally and externally (e.g., with care agencies).
The emotional and physical distress caused to a vulnerable patient by inconsistent messaging.
The unprofessional and dismissive comments made by both physiotherapy and discharge staff.
he failure to ensure dignity and readiness in the attempted discharge (lack of appropriate clothing, preparation, and support).
The misuse of the justification around needing a bed due to a bank holiday, when clear errors had already been acknowledged.

She says the family have a number of questions and they would like the opportunity of a meeting to discuss these with senior staff involved in her mother's care. Initially logged as a PALS concerns Radar reference PALS-3271. Daughter states cancer runs through her family are both sides and her and her siblings have been referred for genetic testing. She has accepted what was recorded on her mother's death certificate, but she thinks her death may have been attributed to something else.

column21: Cooncerns regarding son's appointment in the ENT department at Heartlands Hospital on May 19, 2025. During this visit, we were attended dr who, unfortunately, displayed a troubling level of confusion during our consultation. Pt. who has been diagnosed with Bell's palsy, was repeatedly mistaken for another patient with the same condition. This mix-up not only caused unnecessary confusion but also raised concerns about the attentiveness and accuracy of the care provided.  Deeply concerned about the breach of GDPR regulations that this incident represents. The mishandling of personal information is a serious matter, the hospital to take appropriate steps to ensure that such errors do not happen in the future.

column12: Specialty - Urology BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21:
Complaint regarding the treatment and aftercare I received following a surgical procedure at Heartlands Hospital on 12 May 2025.
I would like this complaint to be formally investigated. Specifically, I want to understand:
1.	Why I was not properly informed of the Botox risks before the day of surgery
2.	Why I was discharged without catheter training or equipment
3.	Why no safeguarding considerations were made in light of my PTSD
4.	Whether this failure constitutes a breach in care under NHS duty of care policies
Needs access to medical records, including the consent form, operative notes, and discharge summary from 12 May.

column12: Specialty - Cardiology QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column19: Missed Deadline – Delay with Medical comments
column20: Delayed medical engagement and comments
column21:
Patient inappropriately discharged from heart failure nurse follow up
No option for any form of community care for patients with heart failure including IV diuresis
No discussion or apparent consideration of palliative care by any member of the cardiology team. 
Admission was refused by consultant without any conversation with the patient and without clear reasoning being communicated.
Patient experienced symptoms of breathlessness, nausea, anxiety and exhaustion for the last weeks of her life that, had palliative care been considered, this could have been better managed and the patient could have had a more comfortable final stage of her life. There would have been opportunity for her and her family to better prepare for her death, and potential to avoid dying in hospital.
Lack of communication with patient and relatives
column22:
13/10/2025 Casework has progressed since the last update. The complaint response letter was finalised for accuracy, with all necessary approvals and sign-off completed 7/10/2025. The letter was sent, and the complaint file has been closed today. Further contact has since been received from the complainant, expressing disappointment and disputing the explanations provided in the response. At this stage, the complainant has indicated they are considering their next steps.
29/09/2025 Complaint Casework – Medical Input Outstanding. Medical comments have been requested and actively chased since 19 August 2025. Escalation has occurred on multiple occasions, including today, due to the continued delay. Hannah Johnson ADoN has confirmed they will be telephoning Prof Leyva directly to obtain the necessary information and ensure the medical review is completed.

column12: Gynaecology Outpatients Department BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column19: Missed Deadline – Delay with Medical comments
column21:
Complaint regarding the ongoing failure to treat symptomatic fibroids effectively, despite multiple documented findings and a surgical intervention that failed to resolve the problem. Remains symptomatic, experiencing irregular and heavy bleeding, has not been appropriately resolved despite prior NHS management.

What I Am Requesting:
1.Written acknowledgement of this complaint within 3 working days.
2.Internal review of the failed procedure and current status.
3.Reinstatement to my original referral position for definitive fibroid removal.
4.Referral to a centre with appropriate instruments for submucosal fibroid resection 
5.A formal apology and assurance this situation will be remedied swiftly.
This has caused me prolonged physical discomfort and emotional frustration. I request this matter be recorded as a clinical incident and that urgent corrective action be taken.

ZK 29/09/2025 12:06 - I placed a call to Dr George Filobbos today and he has stated that he agrees the patient does not have capacity but without and legal paperwork he is unable to perform the procedure on the patient because the patient states he does not feel he needs the elective surgery, but the parents want him to have it. George cannot continue with the surgery without patient consent and without valid documentation that shows the parents are advocates for their son's care. It is a legal requirement. He advised he sent an email to legal and has not had a response. I asked him to send me this email, and I will chase it up as it will support the statements already provided. George also advised that he has requested this paperwork from the family when he sent out his clicn letter but has not yet received anything.

column12: Ward 620 QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column19: Missed Deadline – Delay with Nursing comments
column21: Deteriorating Patient - Episode of gross clinical negligence that occurred during inpatient stay on Ward 620 at Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham on Saturday 7th June 2025. At approximately 7:10pm, experienced a severe anaphylactic reaction, a life-threatening medical emergency requiring immediate and systematic clinical intervention. This reaction was witnessed and reported without delay by a relative to two registered professionals on duty at the time. Despite clear notification of the onset of a medical emergency, the response by both members of staff was wholly inadequate and failed to meet even the most basic standards of clinical care or professional conduct.  Was administered a single dose of 4mg Piriton, with no accompanying clinical observations, no escalation to medical staff, no monitoring, and no initiation of emergency procedures. Both staff members subsequently left the ward at the conclusion of their shift without taking any further action, leaving my condition to deteriorate.

I advised her that her case handler is now Amerjit Lidhar, Carolyn Pitt has been placed as the pint of call for the NMC and we discussed the idea of having a hospital passprt for Ellie to alleviate the extra stress and for her to have a clear pathway set when she attends for urgent treatment. Debbvie is going o send me ans email with what Ellie's needs are and i will then send this onto the vulnerabilities team. She is happy about this as she stated when she comes in the staff do not know how to treat Ellie and she is having to explain this to staff every time. She expressed her satisfaction with the resus team.

ZK 13/06/2025 14:00 - Outcome of 5 day calls placed sent to Gemma Rauer, Rich Lodder and  Am Lidhar.

ZK 13/06/2025 12:08 - Placed call to Ellie Roscoe (patient). I introduced myself and apologised for her experience. I advised that her and mums complaint have both been escalated as a priority to the Ward 620 and others that need to be involved. I asked if she was happy for us to respond to her and mums complaint as one response. She agreed it would be easier and confirmed she is happy for this to happpen. I asked if she was happy for me to liaise with mum too. She advised i can use them both a point of contact. She advised she will be attending on Monday for an appointment and most likely the chances are that she will be admitted for surgery. Her worries are that she will be admitted to ward 620 again and have to deal with facing the staff nurses Leanne and Helen who the complaint is in relation to. She has asked if alternative arrangements can be made if they are on shift that day, I explained i will be on annual leave next week but i will communicate this to my seniors via email and if she has any problems she can call our office and someone will assist her. I provided my direct line.

ZK 13/06/2025 12:35 - Placed a call to patients' mum. Reiterated what i had spoken about with Ellie. She was happy with this too. She explained that she wants to see the level of care for patient improve because her daughter could have lost her life. She has explpained that she does not want Nurse Ellen or Nurse Leanne involved in her daughters' care going forward and asks for alternative arrnagements to be made if Ellie is admitted for surgery on Monday 16 June 2025. She also wanted me to include the following as this was not included in her complaint document... She advised opposite Ellie's bed was an elderly female patient that was being prepared for discharge at 11:30am and was left sitting feeling uncomfortable in the chair until around 7pm. This was only because she requested that the nursing  team arrange a porter to take the elderly lady out to the main entrance.

column12: Specialty - Trauma and Orthopaedics (T&O) GHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column19: Missed Deadline – Delay with Medical comments
column21:
Patient not assessed by a formal doctor at A&E, and a serious UCL rupture was missed at initial presentation.
The injury was subsequently missed by a consultant at the first Fracture Clinic visit.
The ultrasound scan failed to detect the complete rupture, delaying diagnosis further.
The MRI scan undertaken on 22 March, however no action was taken at the 25 April follow-up, losing a critical window for early surgical intervention.
The referral to the specialist team at BCH was made, but no one from Good Hope Hospital has followed up or chased an appointment despite the urgency.
The delays in diagnosis and referral for surgical treatment constitute serious medical negligence.
The quality of life, hand function, and future career of patient may have been permanently compromised due to this chain of clinical failings.

- Liver scan due this morning but couldn't be done as ward had given her breakfast. So had to wait until the afternoon.

column23:
Patient consent is needed and have been unable to obtain. However, we feel it is important to answer the complainant's specific concerns relating to consent. 

Although we have not obtained the patient's consent to share care details, we can and should respond to this complaint. This approach is supported by:

•	Regulation 5 and Regulation 13 of the Local Authority Social Services and National Health Service Complaints (England) Regulations 2009, which allow complaints to be made on someone else's behalf and permit the response to be limited if consent is not provided.
•	The NHS Complaint Standards developed by the Parliamentary and Health Service Ombudsman, which promote a consistent and proportionate approach to complaint handling. These standards recognise that organisations may respond to third-party complaints while respecting patient confidentiality and consent requirements. 

Our response letter therefore does not include any sensitive healthcare information and instead provides clarity on consent processes.

column8: Acute and Short Stay Medicine QEH
column12: Acute Medical Unit (AMU) QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21:
Why would a non specialist consultant jump to a conclusion based on an opinion from a CT scan which clearly states further investigation required.
2.     Why was wife discharged given the diagnosis was unproven?
3.     Why were appointments with Breast Clinic, Haematology and PET not booked as a matter of urgency upon Acute Consultant 'diagnosis'?
4.     Why was my wife discharged on 15th May if RBC blood test results were unknown? QEHB IT systems were down and so any rational person would have expected all discharges to be halted.
5.     Diagnosis from discharge letter on 16th May Dr Neutropenic Sepsis, Unknown Primary? metastasis. 
6.     How did the consultant reach the conclusion that further tests in 'a frail elderly lady with likely metastatic malignancy (it) probably won't add much to the management'? The diagnosis was unproven and my wife was not presenting as a 'frail elderly lady'. We see this a serious failing on the part of the consultant.

column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21: Admitted to Ward 620, Queen Elizabeth Hospital on 3 February 2025 for 3 nights  following a scan for abdominal pain. Informed that he would be having some tests, such as a colonoscopy however this didn't happen and was discharged on 6 February. Told that he was on the list for an urgent colonoscopy as an out-patient. Feels original symptoms in February were treated as insignificant. Informed that there is a possibility that the liver lesions are cancerous and, that if this is the case, they would be secondary cancers and not the primary

column12: Ward 21 (Elderly Care Assessment Unit) BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column19: Missed Deadline – Delay with Nursing comments
column21: PATIENT DEATH IN HOSPITAL - Last Monday patient passed away just after 9.30pm.  28th May patient had a fall and daughter was called and informed about this so she went straight to the hospital where she heard different stories from different staff members. When the doctor initially called to inform her he didn't know how it happened and didn't have any information- complainant questions why he called without having the full details.investigation surrounding the fall – why or how was she allowed to get out of bed when she was meant to be supervised at all times. Why did staff not read notes prior to starting any kind of nursing care with mum when they came on shift. Patient passed away on 2nd June – death was registered on the following day on 3rd June.

column12: Accident & Emergency QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21: Staff attitude towards daughter deep distress and concern regarding an appalling experience my elderly and frail mother and I endured during  visit to Queen Elizabeth Hospital on 11 June 2025, Entire incident was deeply traumatic, not only for daughter but especially for mother, who was already in a life-threatening condition. The behavior of the staff involved was bullying, discriminatory, unprofessional, and negligent. No family member supporting a vulnerable patient should be subjected to such hostile and intimidating treatment—least of all in a hospital that should prioritize empathy, communication, and patient-centred

column12: Ward 12 SH (Solihull Hospital Site)
column21:
First Incident – December 2024 – Left Hand Nerve Damage:
In December 2024, while attending Solihull Hospital for a contrast dye CT scan, multiple unsuccessful attempts were made by the radiology staff to insert a cannula into my left hand. Unfortunately, during these repeated attempts, a nerve was damaged, and I have been experiencing continuous pain and discomfort in my left hand since that incident.
Second Incident – 28 May 2025 – Right Hand Nerve Damage:
Following my mastectomy on 27 May 2025, while still admitted, a blood sample was required on the morning of 28 May. I informed the attending night duty nurse (Nurse Siji) that my veins are difficult to access and requested that a trained phlebotomist be called to take the bloods. Despite my request and prior explanation, Nurse Siji, who stated she had 20 years of experience, proceeded to attempt the blood draw herself. Unfortunately, during the attempt, she failed to obtain blood and caused nerve damage to my right hand. During the procedure, I experienced severe pain and an electric shock-like sensation, which has persisted since.

The patient made a further call to the PALS team on 9th June to provide an update but was more irate and not happy as she was readmitted as the surgical team had missed a lump/abscess which required further surgery.

column12: Ward 17 BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column17: Admissions, Discharges, and Transfers (excluding delayed discharge due to absence of care package)
column21: Complaint regarding the unacceptable delay experienced in the discharge and transport of patient from Ward 17, on 13th June 2025. She was medically cleared for discharge at approximately 1:30 PM, yet she was left waiting for over 12 hours for non-emergency patient transport to return home. Despite being elderly and vulnerable — she is 85 years old — no clear communication or update was provided throughout this delay. She was finally collected at 1:15 AM and did not arrive home until around 1:30 AM. This caused unnecessary physical and emotional distress for both her and our family. Waiting that long in a hospital ward , fully dressed and ready to go, is not acceptable or appropriate for someone of her age and health condition

column21: Daughter concerned that the late mother as not made aware of her last blood test results nor was any action taken by UHB to follow up to address the blood test results on 07/04/25, which were low blood levels & dehydration. Patient was not examined on the visit by the Consultant but instead was advised that it may possibly be lung cancer growth based on old scan results, despite  still waiting upon the latest scan results which were delayed & unavailable .  Blood pressure tests & stethoscope examinations should be a standard examination procedure on patient's with any blood, lung, cancer & terminal illness issues.

*Why did the discharge pharmacy not question this with Pt. when giving her  tto's, they didn't state what she was prescribed, was handed the bag and told to" put the antibiotics in the fridge"

column12: Specialty - Older People's Services (incl OPAL) QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
Deteriorating patinet - Family need some answers  need to know everything that could have been done was done. 
o	The fact that family constantly requested a NG tube but were continuously fobbed off by saying 24 hours over and over.
o	Pt  was refused intervention from ICU saying he was not suitable what I would like to know is what was the medical reason he was refused ICU treatment family was never informed what the clinic reason was. 
o	And what did the Drs see and not inform family of on the day of his admittance to hospital as everything that would have been done previously to treat him was not done. 
o	Why was he continuously given IV drips when he was already over loaded with water retention. When they knew they could not get rid of the water that was already in his system to be giving him more.
o	Why was treatment for him delayed 
fathers medication in his blister pack which clearly has his name on it had another patients sticker put on top had I not been quick to notice it well you know what would have happened
