column12: Ward 517 QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column19: Missed Deadline – Delay with Medical comments
column21: Complaint against the Thoracic Team and how they have communicated and treated pt. following surgery on the 11th April 2025. Admitted QEHB on 11th April 2025 to have a Wedge resection to remove a suspicious tumour which was picked up on a recent PET scan. When Pt. came round from the surgery the surgeon informed her they had removed the tumour and a second lesion from the upper LEFT lobe. This was a shock to her as she was unaware of a second lesion as nothing else had been picked up on the scans. Discharge paperwork stated 'a nodule' was removed so I was confused as to what had been done. The doctor on the ward round on day of discharge confirmed there had been a second lesion removed and histopathology should take around 3-4 weeks to come back. Staff attuide

column12: Labour Ward / Delivery Room BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column19: Missed Deadline – Delay with Medical comments
column21:
Pregnancy and labour/Neonatal  elements: 
•	Multiple appointments at least 4 were cancelled with consultant Anup - SU was told that Anup only had 1 day every 2 weeks for clinics. SU seen Anup at 33 weeks and birthed at 35 weeks. 
•	A different consultant delivered the twins who parent had not met - parent assumed it would be Anup given his speciality.
•	No porter available to take me down to my baby so for the first 2 days I had to reply on my partner when he came to take me down as I wasn't feeling up to walking, 
•	"it was horrible having to leave one of my babies on mat ward alone" as I was told I couldn't take my baby down to my other baby on neonatal. 
•	Due to this I missed food and medication for myself - A midwife even said to me "Are you feeling ok?  Do you want to go down and see your other baby then".
•	Parent found it increasingly stressful trying not to miss baby checks for each of the babies as they were in different locations. No consideration was given for the parents navigating 2 doctors rounds.
•	When on Neonatal - the nurses were openly chatting in front of the SU about what babies were being seen by parents and indicated that SU baby was not seen frequently. 
•	Day 4 a lovely person from the Butterflys team came to me and said I can take my other twin down to neonatal and put him in the cot with my other baby - instantly they both settled. Why did this take 4 days? 
•	Noone came to see Pt. regarding in IF choices - She did get told "someone on the ward would help - but no one came". Parent gave formula. 
•	Badger diary app - Updated it the first day with a couple of messages as though from baby - but no other updates for day 2-5.  Why is this not being used?
•	I asked parent about consent and communication when she wasn't with her baby on neonatal - she said all examinations and assessments were done without consent and communication - this included feeding tube, heel prick, etc i was always told about them after when I visited.
•	Parent was advised that c-section wound would be assessed in community upon discharge - Pt. was told at discharge that she has stiches and staples - The midwife commented to her "I didn't think we did both staples and stiches and proceeded to share that they will be removed in 7-10 days"

column12: Hawthorn House BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21: Patient started treatment with the Immunologist team at Hawthorne House in December, which she was reluctant to do due to her history of complex hypersensitivity to treatment; however, she was reassured surveillance and support would be given.  Five months later, she was too poorly for her double breast surgery due to respiratory issues.   She raised concerns regarding her last clinical letter being incomplete and omitting any reference to her trial of a drug and the response she reported. Patient feels that her concerns and what has happened to her whilst in treatment, has not been addressed.  Although she has been referred to London, she feels that her new symptoms which she asked for advice, she has had to mange herself.  She had a reaction to the contrast when having scan and feels no has helped her. Concerns about SIBO being dismissed.

column21: Patient was discharged in 4 occasion without proper care in place.
column22:
Last updated 27/08/2025:

CASE CLOSED.

ZK 27/08/2025 12:39 - CharIene Mighten advises "completed a capacity assessment with patient Indepth, and he did have capacity to make the decision to return home. 
We offered an access visit to review the property and offered him equipment and a package of care to manage his care needs. All help and support were declined by patient. Based on the mental capacity assessment he fell into the category of making and 'unwise decision'. Home without support was completely his choice and he did give his reasons for not having any support on discharge. "

ZK 27/08/2025 12:29 - Darren confirmed the capacity assessments undertaken deemed the patient to have capacity to make informed decisons about this care so we will need to close this complaint down as we cannot obtain consent from patient. I did attempt to call the son and inform him of this but there was no answer so i have left a vm with my contact number for him to call me back on. I will advise that if in the future his dad changes his mind we will be be happy to look in to this again.

ZK 27/08/2025 08:17 - Darren asking if we have obtained consent because the dad presented with capacity. Darren advises the dad refused treatment and the sons do not agree with the dad's decisions. I had attempted to call the dad but there was no answer so i placed a call to the son who expressed his frustration at the fact that he has shared his complaint with the council, social servise, safeguarding and UHB but Dad is not providing consent so we will most likely need to close this complaint. Dareen will send me an account of the capacity assesment. I will then close the complaint and advise the son of this.

ZK 27/08/2025 08:08 - Reply from WMAS advising they will endevour to respond within 25 days.

ZK 26/08/2025 16:30 - Chaser to request comments from, Adult safeguarding, wmas, Matthew Lloyd and WE2B. Sent to Rachel Goulding, Darren Cleary, WMAS, Matthew Lloyd.

ZK 26/08/2025 15:30 - Complaint sent to Clare Hassan for review.

ZK 20/08/2025 09:21 - Email from BWCH Mykela Capper advising they will try to aim for the deadline.

ZK 19/08/2025 18:14 - Comments requested from WMAS, Adult safeguarding and Harborne medics and nursing.

ZK 03/08/2025 15:04 - Read through complaint, formatted template, started piulling questions but only agreed 3 hours overtime with Am Lidhar so i will need to complete this. To add another 2 questions.

ZK 09/07/2025 17:18 - Attempted to place a call to the complainant but it went staright to voicemail. I left a message stating who i am and for him to call me back on the number i had provided which is my direct line.

ZK  04/08/2025 14:49 - Statement from Dr King

ZK 15/08/2025 16:00 - Complainant called in for an update today and also stated that Dr King has sent a referral letter with a negative tone to the endometreosis team. She wanted advice as she is not confident thedr she is being referred to is friends with Dr King. She also mentioned that she advise him during one of their appointments that she was seen privately by one of his collegues privately in London, he asker her how much he charged and laughed. She feels he does not care about his patients and is aprehensive about her appointment with endo. She feels Dr King has ready broefed him and influenced his clinical decisions. preventing him from undertakingfurther investigations.

ZK 21/07/2025 17:12 - Complaint sent for comments to Thomas Kin, Pushba Sumon, Rupesh Bhatt, Am Lidhar, Alli Page.

ZK 21/07/2025 16:48 - Response provided to complainant advising i have recieved her concerns and i will be sending out for statements today.

ZK 21/07/2025 16:16 - Letter template done by Jo Wilkinson but i will need to look over this as the questions do not cover everything and a further complaint document has been sent in with more details. I had to rv this again and populate the template before requesting for comments.

ZK 11/01/2025 17:32 - Placed a call to complainant, we spoke for almost 30 minutes as she had disclosed alot more information than what was on the PALS form. She asked me to send her an email so that she can send me the email correspondence with Ellis Winter, who Dr King's secratary along with a more detailed account of the events. I explained i need to send this out for statements by Tuesday at the latest amd she said she would do it over the weekend and send it across to me via email. She thanked me and said that i have made her feel alot better as she felt heard. I also stated i would reach out to the Women's hospital and request if an endometriosis specialist would review her as Dr King will not speak to her now. She feels like he has shooed her off. She is deeply unhappy that the MRI scan identified adhesions connecting her womb to her bladder (latter two joined together bc of adhesions), this was communicated to her via her GP but two weeks later Dr King sent out a letter stating there were no findings. When she challenged him on this conflicting information she said he was quite dismissive and said well we can't do anything. As a result she will be informing the Ombudsman and ICB. I had also made some additonal notes on the complaint form.

04/07/2025 SK Complaint launched to officer, Radar reference number COM-1437 and acknowledgment sent.

column12: Ward 12 GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column21: Adult Social Care and General Manager for Complex Discharge Unit emailed Complaints to log a case regarding the Patient's poor care and treatment in the Trust and the lack of empathy and understanding of his condition, lewy body dementia and parkinsons and also poor communication and empathy with the Family; there was also issues with the transfer to a suitable area of the Trust, in particular the denial of being moved to the Elmdon Unit, Solihull Hospital.  Response to be sent to Claire Shannon, Adult Social Care who is leading on complaint; Beverley Bellerby confirmed no consent required as "best interest".
column22:
RW - 25.07.2025 - Teams call completed with Phillip Shakeshaft where I advised him of discussion with Richard Lodder, and that he will need to complete an internal investigation and respond as first requested. Please see attached emails for full details. Provided Phil with CDN questions I pulled from complaint to assist in his internal investigation, and requested that he contact Claire Shannon to update her that the formal complaint is closed and that he will complete investigation and response.
COMPLAINT CLOSED 


RW - 24.07.2025 - Reviewed concerns and compiled questions from complaint into a draft letter template. Noted that complaint came from Adult Social Care Solihill MBC when I was about to launch it to the departments. Upon further review I note that Claire Shannon (Adult Social Care, Solihull MBC) originally advised Phill Shakeshaft (General Manager - Complex Discharge Hubs) that the complaint was not for formal investigation, but is for Phillip to review, consider any learning, and report back to Home First only. I note after a conversation with Claire it was then requested to go through the formal complaints process due to multiple sites. Liaised with Lorna, Marg, and Adrianne - Lorna advised that under National Health Service Complaints Reg 2009 Section 8b, this complaint should not be going through the formal complaints process and advised to liaise with Rich. Informed Rich of above and asked for advice if I should continue to launch the complaint though the formal complaint process or go back to Philip Shakesaft to advise it is for him to review and report to Home First. as I was uncertain about how to move forward since the complainant is not seeking a response, and the request for a response is directed towards an NHS body for the purpose of learning. Rich advised that the case does not fall under legislation 8B. Replied back to Rich to ask if I should still launch the case or return to Phill as the complainant is not aware of the complaint and did not request a formal investigation. Rich advised that based on the original email, this shouldn't be in the complaints process and there is no action for us, and this if for Phil to investigate locally. Email sent to Phill requesting him to advise when able to discuss case. I will then advise him of the above information and close the case.

Further to Beverley Bellerby's confirmation, case logged against CDG4B, GHH, and Solihull to input re complex discharge issues; launched to Officer and sent acknowledgement to Claire Shannon, Adult Social Care; Bev confirmed no consent required as "best interest" and Adult Social Care leading on complaint.
column23: COMPLAINT CLOSED

column12: Specialty - Urology BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21:
Had a catheter fitted between 2017 and it was left and not changed.
Went to Moseley Hall for rehab after having surgery and they tried to remove it wouldn't come out.  They managed to remove it but it bled a lot. They took him back to QE and they re-inserted a new catheter, and he then had regular 3 monthly appointments to change.
He no longer needs to have a catheter but because of this previous issue he now has problems passing water and must wear pads and is up and down going to the toilet every 2 hours.
His life has been messed up since this. Will always have problems.
Messed his life up completely and could have been avoided if he had received the right care.

column21: Patient's mother contacted PALS 10/06/2.  She said her daughter, is under the pain management team at the QE.  She says that Dr  shared his personal opinion during a telephone conversation on 08/05/25.  He said that Pt. should not be taking diclofenac.  She was initially prescribed this by neurology. Dr said diclofenac was not good for her and continued to reiterate she should not be on it. Mother says she has had many discussions over the last few months with healthcare professionals that the medication has been helping Pt.. She says that Dr  sent a letter to their GP and Aroush has will not prescribe further diclofenac.

column12: Gynaecology Outpatients Department GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column19: Missed Deadline – Delay with Medical comments
column21: 9th May, patient attended GHH for a scan and she was asked to return after 10 days.  She attended on 19th and her dating scan was 25th June, where she and her husband were told their baby had no heartbeat.  The patient was given 3 options there and then.  She chose a further scan which was due to take place on 1st July; however, whilst our shopping on 27th June her waters broke, and she was passing blood clots.  On 28th June she was screaming in pain and on the Friday night she tried to call 2nd floor at Fothergill but there was no answer after 16 attempts on both numbers 01214247747 and 01214249604.  The patient called on the Saturday and was advised to still attend for her scan.  She attended for the scan and was advised that she still had part of her in her.  Patient was not happy that due to previous miscarriages, why she was scanned every 2 weeks, why she wasn't given progesterone and why there was there no help for her.

column12: Accident & Emergency QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21: Why was father let to pass away in the most inappropriate place in Hospital it was a  very busy and extremely noisy department not a place for Dad to be in his last hours.  Told by the consultant that we were priority for a bed. Somewhere quiet for  Dad to sleep and have Quiet for his last time on this earth but unfortunately this didn't happen . Secondly. Every time dad needed attending to had to hunt out a member of staff.either to change him or ask for something for him to drink. Even a stalk . The staff never introduced themselves or wore a name badge so I had no idea who or what designation theywere  the last member of staff who came to check  dad  just as he was passing away was extremely tactless not sure they even knew why  Dad was there from their behaviour

column12: Accident & Emergency GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column19: Missed Deadline – Delay with Medical comments
column21:
Complaint regarding the treatment my daughter received in Paediatric A&E on Saturday 6th July 2025, which has caused her significant emotional distress and led to a missed international competition due to a confirmed misdiagnosis
This raises a number of deeply concerning questions:
•	How was this misdiagnosis made?
•	Were the appropriate imaging and reporting procedures followed?
•	Why was there no consideration for a second opinion or review, especially given the importance of the diagnosis to my daughter's circumstances?
•	What systems are in place to prevent such errors, and what actions will be taken to address this failure?

column12: Ward 09 GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column19: Missed Deadline – Delay with Medical comments
column21:
Concerns relating around patient's treatment plan - dissapointed by how reluctant doctors were to carry out investigation . Have requested Pals  to forward  unresolved concerns through formal route 
•	Stroke concerns: PT.  initially presented with symptoms strongly indicative of a third stroke in February 2025, but despite repeated requests, an MRI was delayed for three weeks. By that point, she had already lost her ability to speak. We are still waiting for appropriate follow-up support, including assessment by the Speech and Language Therapy team. No concrete rehabilitation plan has been communicated to us.
•	Urology/Gynaecology concerns: While you note the Women's Hospital is under a different trust, the pain PT.  is experiencing is ongoing and acute. We provided a urology report from December 2024 and raised concerns about lichen sclerosus and possible deterioration. Despite reassurances, no further investigation or intervention has been initiated, and SK continues to suffer.
•	Communication failures: There has been a repeated failure by various consultants and departments to follow through on promised actions, including arranging biopsies, liaising with dermatology, and prescribing effective medication

column12: Accident & Emergency GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
Patient went to A&E at Good hope on 19th June, he presented with chest pain and other symptoms, he was also struggling to walk and breathe.
Patient was eventually seen by a doctor who sent him home saying it was muscular, he should take tramadol and if it didn't improve, he should see his GP.  Patient was not getting any better so was taken to derby royal where he was told he has a collapsed lung. Daughter is frustrated and wants an explanation of why when he presented to A&E with concerning symptoms was he not diagnosed correctly, why was his medical history not reviewed/ flagged up and why were no further investigations done to accurately diagnose him.

column12: Specialty - Neonates UHB (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
Serious concerns regarding the care son and mother received at Heartlands Hospital Maternity Department between 28th December 2024 and 1st January 2025, as well as the bereavement support provided following his death. The way labour was handled left traumatised felt completely unheard, dismissed, and disrespected — as if my pain didn't matter.
After  son was born prematurely at Heartlands on 1st January,  was not permitted to see him for several hours. When mother finally did, was told he had suffered a severe burn to his leg. On 2nd January, saw for burn that his right thigh down to his foot had been badly burned. No explanation was ever provided. This has caused me enormous distress.

column12: Ward 01 BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21:
Pt. discharged from Heartlands hospital Ward 1 on 10th July 2025.
Upon arrival at Sherbourne Grange staff carried out the standard admission assessment, including body map and skin integrity check, and discovered pressure sores on both feet. These wounds appear to have been acquired at Heartlands hospital Ward 1, yet there was no mention of them in the discharge summary, nor were Sherbourne Grange staff informed verbally at any point.

This lack of critical clinical information not only delayed the initiation of appropriate wound care but also placed David at increased risk of infection, pain and deterioration, and compromised the continuity of care expected during transition.

column21: complaint regarding repeated and ongoing failures by NHS services to provide adequate diagnosis or treatment for a severe, long-term skin condition I've been suffering with for over 7 years — suspected scabies. Recently attended Good Hope Hospital A&E, as advised by NHS 111 clearly requested a microscopic test or skin scraping, but was told this was unavailable. Then referred to UTC in Erdington, who again refused to carry out the proper diagnostic test and told must go through my GP. I have already explained to my GP (Jockey Road Medical Centre) that I am facing extreme delays, and they informed me that it may take over 6 weeks just to see a dermatologist.

column19: Missed Deadline –  Delay with response to QA1 queries, Missed Deadline – Delay with Nursing comments
column21: disappointment and distress at the disgraceful care mother received during her visit to the SDEC department on 10/06/2025. Mother waited for 19 hours, suffering in pain without adequate pain relief. The night before, two other doctors, an Asian male and female, were supposed to be attending to patients. However, the male doctor was extremely rude, ignoring patients and spending most of his time on his computer. He would often leave his station for extended periods, leaving patients unattended.dismissive and uninterested. His behavior was unprofessional and inhumane. I'm appalled by the lack of care and compassion shown to my mother and other patients.

column12: Specialty - Urology QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column18: Diagnosis - Delay in acting on test results
column21:
Patient outlining recent experience of post-biopsy sepsis following a procedure at Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham on 14 July.
Was  individual risk adequately assessed and communicated? Pt had a  very large prostate, which is recorded in records and which now understand may make transperineal biopsy under anaesthetic both safer and more diagnostically accurate. I was given one a few years ago by doctor but this alternative was not discussed with him on this  occasion.
•
Was appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis given, and is UHB reviewing its infection control protocols given the growing recognition of resistant rectal flora and increasing sepsis rates?
•
Can  case be formally reviewed, and will it be used to inform changes in biopsy practice or patient information?

column21:
appalling care and medical negligence received from the Gynaecologist team  haD previously made a complaint (JLA/1200) and was sent an email on 18/02/2025 confirming that my concerns were raised with the team. However, not received any further outcome or call from my Gynaecology team to discuss my previous concerns. Now making a further complaint about the medical negligence   . Prostap, given without proper informed consent about its potential side effects, including temporary menopause. told about the need for HRT, now experiencing unnecessary physical and mental health impacts as a result.

perienced with Dr. and Oncology Specialist  - given wrong injection

Patient stated she 'does not see the point in PALS', and not having a written response 'is a waste of time'. Patient also unhappy at the time frame the concern has been open.

column12: Ward 16 GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column21:
Summary of Concerns
•
No observations were taken from lunchtime on 2nd July through the morning of 3rd July - over 18 hours - despite my being monitored for low blood pressure and high heart rate.
•
False readings were recorded in my medical records, including:
•
Observations that were never carried out
•  A pain score of 0, which is inaccurate
•
I was dismissed and disbelieved, despite multiple witnesses
•
Nurse implied that because other nurde had reported the observations were done, it must be true - and minimised the validity of my distress and my witnesses
•
Pt.  left distressed, anxious and extremely concerned - not only for my own safety, but for that of other patients who may not be able to speak up

column12: Specialty - Upper GI Surgery BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21:
Patient went to Heartlands hospital on 12th May wit stomach and chest pain. Got to A&E  was discharged with the advise to go home and not eat bread, cakes, spicy food, etc and take pain relief, they didn't give a discharge letter. When they sent discharge note to GP they put it down to gastroenteritis.
The next day patient couldn't eat and was in agony with pain getting worse, so she went to SH where they did a urine sample and checked temp, they said it is the gallbladder so wrote a letter and told her to go back to Heartlands immediately.
Patient went straight to ward 19 where they did more tests and scans where it turned out she has sepsis and perforated gallbladder. 
Patient was very upset as this could have been dealt with earlier when she initially went to A&E with her symptoms.
They couldn't remove gallbladder as it was too dangerous for them with risk of sepsis going into blood stream.

column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
Request face to face meeting -  Moms diagnosis of cancer. What scans were done. Decision for no treatment, and how this would affect her.
 The conflicting information given from different doctors and consultants.
 Moms last two admissions to the hospital. The decisions not to give her IV antibiotics and fluids on the overnight admission. The decision to discharge her made before the ward round and early call to me at 8.30 in the morning from Caroline the discharge co ordinator on AMU. The envelope left on moms table with a note stating not fit for discharge. This resulted in the the gold standard care package not being in place on her discharge and our need to call the GP paramedic out to her.

ZK 08/08/2025 13:38 - 14:01 - Placed call to complainant (patients daughter) to introduce myself and advise i have been assigned as her case handler. I asked how her father was doing now and she advised since his first surgery with Dr Puig he has never fully recovered despite having the emergency surgery at Walsall Manor. She explained he could still do school runs etc prior to his surgery and now he is unable and is constantly in pain and vomitting. She explained that Dr Puig was very umempathetic when his pain levels were flagged to her, her attitude was stern and passive like she did not care. Complainant advises her father is very dissapointed with Dr Puig attitude and is not willing to undergo any further care with her due to his experience. I also advised that she will need to request for the SAR herself and i will send her over the details.

Launched to Officer, sent acknowledgement and requested consent; also linked serious incident SE-67885 which relates to this case.

column12: Specialty - Cardiology BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column18: Diagnosis - Delay in acting on test results
column21:
serious clinical and administrative failures, including negligent follow-up after critical test results, dismissive communication, and systemic delays in treatment.

Key issues include:
1.	Failure to escalate urgent findings (e.g., potential aortic clot identified during echocardiogram on 16th July 2025, with no immediate clinician review).
2.	Unprofessional conduct (e.g., CT department staff abruptly ending my call when I sought clarity on an urgent scan).
3.	Lack of post-TIA care (e.g., promised follow-up scans/monitoring not delivered promptly after my 26th June 2025 admission).

column12: Specialty - Neurosurgery QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
Concerns raised regarding delay in surgery and cancellation of appointments. Patient has requested escalation to a complaint due to the delays as he has living with a section of his skull leaving him vulnerable to a life-altering injury, has been unable to return to work due to the physical risks, the significant impact of on his mental health, family and social life.  He feels that the delay in follow-up and the lack of earlier surgical planning has directly contributed to a prolonged deterioration in his quality of life.  He is requesting a formal investigation into:

•	Why my follow-up appointment was delayed for so many months
•	Why I was not placed on the surgery list much sooner
•	What steps are being taken to ensure that patients in similarly vulnerable positions do not face such delays in the future

column12: Ward 620 QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21:
Complaint concerning the standard of care and treatment provided to Pt during her admissions to your hospital between 7th July 2025 and 23rd July 2025.  Family deeply concerned that the treatment she received during this period fell significantly below the expected standard of clinical care and appears to constitute a breach of duty, resulting in avoidable harm, both physical and emotional.

1. Inadequate Initial Diagnosis and Discharge (7th–9th July 2025)
2. Administration of Incorrect Medication (15th July 2025)
3. Inappropriate Prescribing of Senna Laxatives (15th–18th July 2025)
4. Degrading and Undignified Care (21st July 2025)

column12: Accident & Emergency QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21:
-	No apology from doctor, remains unhappy and feels he was asking if she was on recreational drugs 
-	She says the result of sitting in hard chairs for a long period of time on this admission has resulted in her now struggling with back pain 
-	Despite the below feedback she feels that the CT was not done properly, and the results (which confirmed no issues) were probably looking at bigger masses when she was sent for a possible 'mini stroke' 
-	She disagrees with the diagnosis of stress 
-	She is unhappy with PALS and feels that they did not record her concerns down properly. I assured her that her concerns were recorded down twice (once by advisor taking the initially call, and again by myself).

column12: Ward 15 GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column19: Missed Deadline – Delay with Nursing comments
column21:
Patient's son says his mother was on GHH Ward 15 from 06/07/25 to 18/07/25.  His mother has an ulcer on her right leg which was being managed well by District Nurse prior to her admission. 

During her admission, Mr Graham says that he and his mother were asking about her leg ulcer care. They were told that dressings were changed every two days.

His mother was discharged home and a few days letter was readmitted on 21/07/25 because her leg ulcer was infected. She had to be brought in by ambulance and her son says the infection is so serious that the doctor said you can see the patient's tendons.

column12: Accident & Emergency QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21: Pt. was bought in by ambulance today, he tried to call daughterto ask her to pick him up, unfortunately he is hard of hearing and didn't tell her where to collect him and what the outcome was concerning his health. Tried to call A & E switchboard put her through it rang out, back to switchboard put through to A & E cut off again this cycle continued for 25 minutes then eventually  got out through to patient records  explained situation and was put on hold, after 5 minutes was cut off again, rang reception yet again and the cycle continued, was given the direct number and rang the number ten times .. no response,  cannot get any information about father, don't know where he is in the hospital and he is waiting somewhere for me thinking she is picking him up !. terrible service .. no one cares unfortunately

4. Delay in Administering Pain Medication
5. Labelling of Behaviour as 'Aggression'
6. Lack of Transparency and Communication Around Care Planning
7. Distressing and Conflicting End-of-Life Decisions
8. Theft and Lack of Stimulation for Patient

column12: Specialty - Obstetrics UHB (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21: Complaint regarding the care received during and after emergency caesarean section at Heartlands Hospital on 15 July 2025.During the surgery suffered a 5-centimetre tear in my bladder, told about while still lying on the operating table. No interpreter was present. Neither I nor husband speak fluent English, and husband had to use a translation app on his phone to try to understand what was happening. It was not clear or reassuring. In fact, it increased fear and confusion. Two weeks prior to the surgery,  had signed a consent form with a midwife who spoke Arabic. General risks of caesarean delivery were explained, but no mention was made of possible bladder or uterine injury. At the time, was also suffering from depression and anxiety  informed the team about. Unfortunately, no special care or mental health support was offered during or after the surgery.

column12: Specialty - Acute and Short Stay Medicine BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column17: Admissions, Discharges, and Transfers (excluding delayed discharge due to absence of care package)
column21:
Upon retun of patient to care home he was in a significantly worse medical condition than when he was admitted. Alarmingly, the discharge papers provided to the care home were for an 18-year-old female, and there was no verbal handover from the hospital to the care home staff. Additionally, his Parkinson's medication schedule was altered during his hospital stay, and he was discharged with new medication but without any explanation or administration timings.
We are also requesting:
•	A full account of the treatment provided during his stay.
•	Documentation explaining the changes to his medication.
•	Copies of discharge summaries and communications with the care home.
•	Any incident reports or safeguarding assessments related to this admission and discharge.

PRESSURE ULCERS:  Deceased Patient's Husband emailed re the result of a Coroner's report which stated that along with his Wife's cancer, an infected pressure sore was the cause of her death; Complainant would like this investigated due to the poor treatment she received on Ward 19 SH prior to her discharge;  Complainant was also unhappy that she was admitted to a general medicine ward and not an Oncology Ward at the time.
NB:  Patient had also spent 4 weeks in BHH prior to the transfer to Solihull; there is an Incident logged on Radar for SH regarding the pressure sore (SE-4121); Patient had to be readmitted to BHH regarding the sore; she was discharged and passed away a few days later at home.

column12: Ward 16 GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21: Patient spent nine weeks under Good Hope Hospital's care — much of it in extreme pain, with a proven spinal infection that has received no treatment. Despite repeated admissions, he has been discharged multiple times without proper diagnosis, and only recently was a spinal abscess discovered — by which time his condition had deteriorated from being a full-time digger driver to being bedbound, on permanent morphine, and unable to stand. The delays and mismanagement in his care have been unacceptable and have caused irreparable harm

column12: Accident & Emergency BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21: Pt. brought into ED on 22/06/25 by (blue lighted) ambulance with suspected stroke.  He says he arrived at 06:00 and it took 12 hours of sitting on a hard and uncomfortable chair before he was reviewed by a doctor.  He says he waited for a CT scan for multiple damaged discs and full body numbness on one side.  He was reviewed by Dr at 1800 who said he needed a full MRI and a discussion with a consultant. It got to 20:00 and Pt. was still waiting.  He says he asked the nurse in charge for an update and was told it could take up to 24 hours of waiting.  He says this is dangerous and someone should be held accountable.

column12: Accident & Emergency BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21:
Complaint regarding the unacceptable care and treatment  received at Heartlands Hospital on two separate occasions. seeking a full explanation for the events that transpired, as my health has significantly worsened since these incidents, and I remain without a diagnosis.
* Why a life-threatening condition, as determined by both 111 and my GP, was not treated as an emergency on either visit.
 
* Why I was told I would receive an endoscopy and then denied this procedure after waiting for 18 hours.
 
* Why I was treated with such disrespect, and why the staff refused to return my GP's letter.
 
* Why, after spending a combined total of over 30 hours in your hospital, I left without any diagnosis, meaningful checks, explanation and treatment.

column12: Ward 625 QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21:
Prior to patient's death famil  had mutilple conversations with doctors, nurses, Pallative care and Oncology to state that any medication changes or issues were to be discussed with daughter or brother patient's next of kin's. Especially as patient was not fully compos mentis due to the mutilple medications she was on and cancer on the brain growing. 
As a direct result, patient suffered a seizure on 8th May 2025 at 11:15pm.  Family believe this significantly accelerated her decline. Furthermore, it appears that:
• The medical records were falsified to indicate that medication had been declined when it had not.
• Oncology were not notified of the "declining" of medication.
• The ward team demonstrated a lack of understanding of the serious consequences of abruptly stopping steroids, which should

column12: Accident & Emergency QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
Complaint regarding  attendance at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital Emergency Department on 13th August 2025, following recent spinal surgery. Deeply concerned about the negligence, mismanagement, and lack of communication experienced, which placed patient at significant risk and forced me to self-discharge due to unsafe care. Requesting 
1.	A full investigation into why symptoms were dismissed and why sepsis, autoimmune flare, or neurological issues were not adequately investigated.
2.	Copies of all investigations and blood cultures, including ECG, CRP, WCC, neutrophils, and MSU results.
3.	A corrected and detailed discharge letter (August 2025), including all investigations, abnormal results, and follow-up actions AND review and correction of my previous spinal surgery discharge letter, which remains incomplete (July 2025)
4.	Urgent referral and review by rheumatology and nerve specialists.
5.	Clarification on what follow-up is planned for my elevated CRP, weight loss, and multi-systemic symptoms.
6.	Review why my GP-requested investigations, including a chest X-ray, were not carried out.

PATIENT DEATH IN HOSPITAL - Patient diagnosed with an inoperable brain tumour.  Advised that patient was boaderline diabetic but and that the medication needed to be changed.  
Could the lack of diabetes medication have caused patient to get the cellulitis in the first place ? (Dr SD said it was possible due to the steroids)
Why wasn't we told she was diabetic and given insulin when the Drs at the medical Center and hospital clearly knew ?
Why did it take so long for the Insulin levels to be taken under control before the met forming was used knowing there was no response from the new insulin for weeks ?
Why were antibiotics stopped if there was still clearly a problem with her legs ?

column21:
concerns regarding the community midwife service after the birth of my daughter: Key Issues:

•	Only received one community midwife visit after discharge.
•	Baby diagnosed with jaundice at first visit, sent back to hospital, but no follow-up support afterwards.
•	Repeatedly called the community midwife number every day for a week, left voicemails — no response.
•	On 20th August, someone finally answered and said they would email the midwife team, but I never heard back.
•	Baby's jaundice worsened had to take her to GP, who referred us to A&E at Heartlands. Staff there questioned why the midwife had not been in touch.
•	postnatal stitches were never checked, left in  pain and struggling to care for my newborn.

column12: Specialty - Urology QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21:
Complaint regarding  treatment and aftercare received QEHB Urology Department on 14 May 2025, Underwent Shockwave Lithotripsy for a 6mm kidney stone in my right kidney. Concerns are as follows:
1.	Lack of post-procedure monitoring or observation following the lithotripsy, particularly after reporting significant pain during the treatment.
2.	Inadequate discharge process, including failure to provide discharge notes or ensure reliable contact numbers for post-procedure complications.
3.	Breakdown in communication, which led to delays in receiving urgent care and contributed to unnecessary distress and risk to my health.
4.	Lack of follow-up after discharge, leaving me uncertain about the long-term implications of the injury to my kidney.

column12: Specialty - Haematology UHB (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
complaint regarding the care provided to my late husband, under the haematology team in 2021–2022. Believe that serious failings in his care contributed to his decline and eventual death.
Concerns 
Despite these plans, we are concerned that:
1. Delays occurred in arranging the PET scan and stem cell transplant, leaving patientvulnerable to disease progression.
2. Communication between teams (haematology, cardiology, and the GP) was poor, leading to confusion about his medication management and care pathway.
3. Opportunities for earlier intervention may have been missed, despite his clear chemo-sensitive response, reducing his chances of a successful outcome.
4. As a result, patient's health deteriorated, and he sadly passed away.

column21: Concerns raised with DNR on patient's records. Mother  is of sound mind and competent in making decisions regarding her own health and is exercising her human right to chose not to have a DNR in place. There was no acknowledgement of this despite us raising this concern, nor any indication of any action to revoke the DNR. In summary nothing we highlighted has been acted on.

column12: Ward 621/SAU QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column19: Missed Deadline –  Delay with response to QA3 queries
column21:
Patient left in broken reclining chair for over 20 hours, which has caused bruising and extreme pain to patient's back and posterior. 
Lack of communication from staff as to what was happening.
No facilities for washing other than the public toilets and nowhere for privacy or to keep personal belongings.  
Available fluids were on request only with no access to drinks when needed.  Patient did not get a cup of tea until the second day.
Patient was discharged on the provision that he return if his condition worsened, as staff agreed that keeping patient in a broken chair was not helping his condition.

column12: Ward 17 BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column19: Missed Deadline – Delay with Medical comments
column21: complaint with regards to treatment received at Heartlands Hospital following a hip fracture which is the secondary cause of her death. No physiotherapy guidance was given on this discharge summary or during inpatient stay, and the GP later wrote to Physiotherapy services and the Hip clinic at ROH, stating she was "discharged with no follow up."  She was reviewed by the Royal Orthopaedic Hospital clinic team on 14th April 2025. The imaging showing failed osteosynthesis of the original fracture October 23, and further fractures (intracapsular fracture and femoral head displacement due to IM nail screw metalwork pressure). This led to her requiring a complex total hip replacement surgery which she unfortunately did not survive.

column8: Acute and Short Stay Medicine QEH
column12: Acute Medical Unit (AMU) QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21:
24th May patient had a stroke and pneumonia for which she was given a 5 day course of antibiotics. 
7th June – Patient was sweating and was poorly, she was seen by badger clinic who sent her to QEH AMU with a letter
Patient has been waiting most of the day to be seen by doctor.
Arrived at 12pm – it was now nearly 9pm and no doctor had seen patient.
A nurse came back and mentioned there is problem with  dimer which caused daughter to panic as she knows what this means considering mums medical history. Daughter was concerned her mum could have a pulmonary embolism. Eventually Dr  came on shift, daughter stated she expressed her concerns regarding her mum and delays for her to be seen - from the first interaction her attitude was off, 'if looks could kill', doctor was not professional, not listening and refused to see mum. In the end mum had to be seen by another Dr who was understanding.
Daughter wants to raise complaint about this doctor and her attitude which was inappropriate at the time and how she dealt with the situation.

column12: Ward 12 BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
Patient death in hospital - serious negligence and failures in duty of care contributed to his suffering and to the circumstances surrounding his death.
•	Delay in specialist referral and inadequate early intervention despite abnormal liver enzyme results and jaundice.
•	Lack of communication regarding test results, scans, and treatment plans, leaving the family uninformed.
•	Failure to provide daily medical reviews as required for a case of this severity.
•	Neglect of basic care needs: his catheter bag was often left full, hygiene standards were poor, and my father was left unattended for long periods without being cleaned or repositioned.
•	Unnecessary or unexplained medication: paracetamol was given regularly without justification.
•	Discrimination and lack of dignity: staff dismissed my role as translator, showed disrespect when he spoke his own language, and a nurse named Aney in particular discriminated against my family.
•	Denial of family contact: when the ward was closed due to flu, we were not allowed to speak with or reassure my father. Requests to explain the situation to him by phone were refused. This deprived him of the comfort of his loved ones during his final days, leaving him frightened and alone.
•	Delay in informing the family of his deterioration: we were only told three days after doctors knew his condition was worsening, despite being present daily and providing contact details.
•	Undignified end-of-life care: staff failed to provide privacy or compassion during his last moments, with nurses staring through curtains as he lay dying.
•	Poor hygiene standards: throughout his admission, I observed inadequate cleaning and infection control, which may have contributed to his decline.

Complaint with regards to the way patient was treated on ward .•Family we outraged and disappointed that the information about  father's fall were not the full facts and that  as a family had been misled by Ward 9 staff in being told he had had a fall when the facts are that he was pushed over by a nurse forcing their way into the bathroom . Further that rather than tending to him that member of staff left the scene leaving other staff to attend to him when he screamed out for help.

•	want assurance that all the necessary scans /x-rays had been undertaken to determine my fathers injuries 
•	that we were disappointed that it took 3 days and numerous calls from myself to the Ward on the 26/08/25; 27/08/25 and the 28/09/25 before a dip test was completed to diagnose that my father had a UTI leading to a delay in administration of the necessary anti - biotics and unnecessary distress and confusion for my father and distress to the family.

column12: Specialty - Neurosurgery QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
Patient had neurosurgery on 24th March. Saw the consultant post op on the ward and in April where she told him she has been experiencing more symptoms, he dismissed her concerns stating it will take 18 months for her to fully recover. Her symptoms include weakness in right hand/ shoulder, weak grips, things falling out of hands. No sensation in right leg. Why was she not told at any point she had a minor stroke during surgery.Why was she given inaccurate information regarding her symptoms and recovery time.
Why did the procedure take 9.5 hours which nearly double the amount of time it should usually take.
Where there any complications and if so what.
Are her symptoms permanent.

column12: Accident & Emergency GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column21: father is currently receiving end-of-life care for cancer that has spread to his lungs, liver, and brain. He is severely confused, cognitively impaired, and emotionally distressed. He also has longstanding traits consistent with autism and ADHD, which I explicitly disclosed to staff during his admission. Staff failed to make reasonable adjustments to his care, despite being informed of his sensory and cognitive needs. No effort was made to ensure my father understood what was happening or to reduce his distress other than sedating him which wouldn't have been necessary had he been treated with respect to his disabilities.

column12: Acute Medical Unit (AMU) QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column19: Missed Deadline – Delay with Nursing comments
column21: Concerns surroundng Pressure area care and mobilisation.  Infection contol contracted MRSA ask whether infection-prevention measures were followed and whether treatment was appropriate during his initial admission? Nutrition and hydration staff declined vouchers provided by ward. His nutritional intake therefore remained poor and his weight fell markedly. Would like to know why his nutrition was not better supported. No leg injury was present, yet he was not mobilised and is now unable to walk. What physiotherapy was planned and delivered during his inpatient stay?Following my grandmother's death on 26 April 2025, no bereavement or psychological support was offered to him. Failed discharge grandaughter not informed when patient was discharged

column12: Ward 621/SAU QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21: Medical Negligence. The incision and drainage perianal abscess surgery done on 8/9/25 was not dressed properly before i was discharged. On 9/9/25, i started bleeding profusely from the wound around 1030 am. I rang 111 and was advised to go back to the hospital. Despite the notes sent to the hospital by the Ambulance advisor for quick intervention and my reapeated complaints of bleeding, dizziness, weakness, pains and constipation to the doctors, i was not attended to until 2300 hrs from my arrival time on the ward.. I was soaking wet with blood on my two pants, a joggers and a pad for support.

column21:
Complaint about the care received following kidney transplant at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in 2014
Conduct a full investigation into why the stent was not removed when it should have been.
•
Provide an explanation of what follow-up protocols were in place at the time for transplant patients with stents, and why I was not recalled or contacted.
•
Confirm how this oversight happened and what lessons have been learned.
•
Provide reassurance that changes have been made to ensure no other patient experiences the same failure in follow-up care.
•
Formally acknowledge the impact this has had on my health and wellbeing and provide an apology.

•	Was there no sign of sepsis earlier?

column12: Accident & Emergency BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column18: Mental health issue - Treatment of patient with
column21:
Patient feels she was unlawfully detained, in breach of Section 2 of the Mental Health Act, in the A&E department.
Patient feels that she was not provided with any legal or clinical rationale for the sectioning, nor was she given the opportunity to understand her rights. The psychiatrist explicitly stated she didn't need to explain their decision.
Patient states that she was threatened with arrest by a nurse who informed her that if she attempted to leave A&E, she would be arrested - this was despite patient showing no signs of aggression or risk.
Patient feels that there was a failure of Duty of Care as the conduct of the psychiatrist and social worker failed to meet professional standards of transparency, informed consent and patient dignity.

column8: Acute and Short Stay Medicine QEH
column12: Acute Medical Unit (AMU) QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
No post-procedure discharge summary or safety-netting pathway to urology. Nor discharge summary or results from first A&E attendance.
 •           Failure to recognise/act on sepsis early: no timely blood/urine cultures, no early antibiotics, despite rising inflammatory markers and red flags.
 •           Delayed senior review and escalation across ED/AMU for an 81-year-old with 10/10 pain, retention, delirium, and distension.
 •           Inadequate analgesia and prolonged ED waits; pain relief requests ignored.
 •           Delayed MRI despite features compatible with spinal infection; over-reliance on normal x-ray/CT.
 •           Poor communication and documentation: multiple encounters without summaries; family not informed of CRP 164 for days. And not acted on by medical team.
 •           Visiting/exclusion issue: threat of security while basic care (overdue analgesia, bladder scan) was outstanding.
 •           Delirium not actively recognised/managed; family not engaged to support orientation/decisions.
  •           Questionable differential reasoning (e.g., TB) without correlating features; risk of stereotype-driven anchoring.
  •           Proposal to stop effective antibiotics to obtain cultures after improvement, risking deterioration. And proposal invasive investigation.

column12: Cedar Ward BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21:
Complaint regarding the care received following the birth of my first child by caesarean section on 08/09/2025. The treatment experienced left me in unnecessary pain and distress, believes that both herself and baby were put at risk due to the standard of care provided.
Following my caesarean, wound was incorrectly stapled, with staples doubled up on top of each other. This caused significant pain and complications with my recovery as it has now led to an infection.
Prescribed medication was not ready for collection until three days after discharged, leaving  without the essential pain relief and treatment I required during that time.
Wound began leaking, was scheduled for a scan just four days postpartum. During this procedure, the sonographer pressed down firmly on my wound site, which was extremely painful and inappropriate given the circumstances. Lack of inadquate nursing care

column12: Specialty - Trauma and Orthopaedics (T&O) BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21: Patient was brought into Heartlands Hospital  A& E 10/08/25 3pm after waiting in an ambulance for a few hours. She had a dislocated hip replacement and was in tremendous pain. She was supposed to be operated on in the morning but that didn't happen as there wasn't a bed for her. She had some morphine had been trying to see a consultant all day to get pain relief with no luck. The nurses had tried to get a doctor to come and see her and prescribe but no one was responding to their requests (she believes about 10 times). She was unhappy with the amount of time she was left in terrible pain and lack of response from the doctors.

column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21: unhappy with lack of treatment in ED - arrived witih stroke system.  Despite presenting with classic red flag stroke symptoms, was placed in urgent emergency and left waiting for almost two hours. During this time, Irepeatedly approached staff (at least five times) to explain that mcondition was worsening, yet was spoken to rudely, dismissively, and told simply to "wait". Felt as though was being deliberately ignored, even though situation was deteriorating.•The reception nurses repeatedly dismissed me and spoke in a rude and raised tone, despite my worsening state.

column21: Deceased Patient's Son and representative for the Family re the failings in the care and treatment of his late Father on Ward 622, QEHB; Complainant believes that the care provided breached several statutory obligations and national healthcare standards.  This includes lack of dignity in his personal care, communication, and discharge; failures in administering medication and poor infection control; inadequate provision of food and hydration and insensitive end of life communication both with Patient and Family.

column12: Specialty - Breast Care UHB (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column19: Missed Deadline – Delay with Medical comments
column21: On 8 August 2024, during a breast clinic visit with Dr. Souganthy Sundaramoorthy, I raised concerns about an itchy circular mark on my left nipple that had been present since March, but the doctor dismissed it and advised me to see my GP. Feeling ignored, I contacted breast care nurses, who reiterated that if the doctor had no concerns, neither did they. My GP later referred me to dermatology, where after several appointments—including a biopsy in June 2025—I was diagnosed on 14 July 2025 with basal cell carcinoma of the nipple, and treatment began immediately. On 6 August 2025, I learned my upcoming breast clinic appointment was canceled due to a system change I was never informed about. Given this misdiagnosis and my history, I am requesting a detailed breast scan (not just a mammogram) to check for duct involvement, as Dr. Sundaramoorthy failed to address my concerns and overlooked cancer symptoms.

column12: Accident & Emergency BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21:
Complainant's mum was taken to Heartlands hospital on 27th August, she had suspected sepsis and was treated with antibiotics.
She has Parkinson and onset dementia so her husband was there with her al night..
Respect form was done at 06.46am but nothing was discussed with her husband/ NOK.
Later that afternoon she got a call saying she needs to come in.
When she arrived her mum was not there as she was taken for a scan. She was told that her mum is really poorly, they are trying but family need to prepare for the worst. 
They were then given a family room between majors B and resus. 
A doctor came and said to grandson without checking who he is – that patient has had a heart attack and has a tear in heart.
Why did this doctor not tell patient's husband/ NOK or her other three children, why did he tell grandson whilst they were present or he could have gathered the family together.

Patient passed away the following day.
They did not do anything to save her.
They didn't give a full explanation as to why they are not saving her
They made a decision to leave a 67 year old to die, what was their rationale behind this.
They did not discuss with the family any other options/ treatment.
Daughter said she has a lot of unanswered questions and wants a complaint to be raised so she can get some answers.

column12: Edgbaston Unit QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21:
Complainant has asked numerous concerns around patient's death:
1. Did he die in his sleep?
2. Were his eyes open at the time of death and if so who closed them?
3. The names of the doctors involved? 
4. What did he eat overnight and did he eat all of it?
5. Did he get sleep most of the night or could he not get sleep?
6. What was he's blood pressure at the time of death or the last time it was checked? 
7. What was his blood sugars at the time of death or the last time it was checked? 
8. What was his blood cultures results?
9. What was his temperature reading at the time of death or last time it was checked?
10. When his blood cultures were taken they took a lot of blood and he had very low appetite so if he did not eat or drink enough could this have contributed to his death? 
11. Concerns also around why it took 4 days for son to receive his father's body.  He is Muslim and needed to be buried quickly.  Query around doctor signing death certificate.

column12: Centre for Clinical Haematology QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column18: Delay or failure in acting on reports
column21:
Why was the patient not told in June 2025 that the NHS would not commission a second transplant.
Why did it take 6 weeks (post scoping etc) to realise that a second allograft would not be possible?
Why was the patient told that the NHSE had rejected commissioning of the second allograft when nothing was ever submitted to the ICB for funding approval? It was the Birmingham Haematology team who took the decision not to pursue funding due to the published NHS commissioning criteria.
Why did the Director of Transplants need to seek counsel to raise an IFR and why were they not aware of the process?
Why did the Director of Transplants agree to submit an IFR but then retract this due to not gaining MDT approval? 
Why did they not know that they needed to gain MDT approval?
Why did the MDT not agree to an IFR request being raised as the budget is not held by them and are not allowing the patient a chance to have her case heard by their local ICB together with her MP. 
Patient asked to attend the next MDT to put forward her case but was told this was not possible and there were no further routes to appeal the decision. How can you not have an appeals process that does not involve the patient?

column12: Accident & Emergency QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
Patient emailed PALS, submitted webform and called Complaints office re the poor care and treatment she received at A&E, QEHB, in particular the Patient has raised the following issues:

1. Why I was left waiting for hours without communication or treatment.
2. Why my GP referral and symptoms were dismissed.
3. Why diagnostic imaging was not performed to confirm or rule out a Seroma.
4. Why an aspiration was attempted in the wrong area, causing unnecessary pain and potential harm.
5. Why a pattern of repeated dismissal has occurred despite clear evidence of Seroma in previous visits.
6. What steps will be taken to ensure patients are treated with professionalism, respect, and accuracy in future.
NB:  Patient states the admission date was 27.09, but according to Portal it was 03.10.

Patient also sent in another email regarding another visit to A&E on 03.11 re the same issues and has requested an urgent ultrasound-guided aspiration procedure.

column12: Fracture Clinic GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column21: I had a call at 9.30am on the 30 october with dr A Seaminathan regarding my results for a MRI. First call came in at 9.50am and he did not speak. Then I called the hospital back several times saying is he calling me back and the nurse John said he had tried 3 times which is a lie as I had no miss calls from the hospital. I said I want to make a complaint and then I got a call straight away. The doctor then said no fracture etc and was about to get off the phone. Please request a recoding of this call which wa approx 10.50am I said I have the report so tell me what it showed again he then read it and I said it is showing somthing. He said yes early arthritis and we only deal with fractures/trauma and I can come in next week. I refused to come in as he didn't say for what I said what will you be doing as I still have pain and am not weight bearing on right hand. You won't just do nothing you have to refer me. Finally got a referral but maybe to the wrong department. This is unacceptable behaviour by the hospital and doctor. I pay my taxes to be seen if I have an issue. I am right handed and am experiencing so much pain for a doctor to just disregard it and do nothing about it. I understand it is not a fracture but signpost me to another department. If I have onset of artiritis surely this had to be actioned now. Or do the nhs have a habit of doing nothing unless it gets worse I want ti make a complaint

column12: Accident & Emergency GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column21: On 29th September, Alex attended A&E with a football-related ankle injury and was misdiagnosed with a minor heel chip; he was discharged without a cast and given crutches without instruction. At the Fracture Clinic on 7th October, a proper diagnosis revealed a significant tibia fracture requiring urgent surgery due to the delay. This has caused distress and disrupted Alex's athletic activities. We request a full investigation into the missed diagnosis, X-ray review process, discharge protocols, care standards, and preventative measures to avoid similar errors.

column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
1.	On page 4, it states that registration and e-triage form was completed at 5:00am, and Natalie Martin was assessed at 11:00am and referred to SAU. These times are incorrect by an hour each, which we are assuming is a typo on your part. Registration and e-triage form was completed at 4:00am, and Ms Martin was referred at 10:00am. We know this due to an uber receipt/timestamps from messages sent that are still available if you require evidence of this. 
2.	On page 1-2, it is stated that Natalie Martin had a four-hour wait to be seen between bloods taken and being seen by a doctor. This is incorrect, by your own timings provided. The timings between bloods taken and being transferred was 7 hours. Even if the timings are corrected to our timings, this is still a 7 hour wait. Please could you correct this and reconsider if "care was still managed appropriately according to the information available."

column12: Ward 16 GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column21: Unhappy with care and treatment whilst on Ward 16 at GHH.
column22:
22/12/25 - OM - approved with changes at QA2 by T Farmah, sent for QA3. approved at QA1 by R Lodder, sent for QA2
RW -18.12.2025 - Sent to drafting support
10/12/25 - OM - Comments received from T Farmah, ready to draft
RW - 21.11.2025 - I contacted the complainant at her request to discuss her concerns and explain the complaints process. During the conversation, the complainant was articulate and appeared to have capacity.
I outlined the complaints procedure and confirmed that her concerns regarding Ward 16 are under investigation, and she will receive a written response. The complainant expressed dissatisfaction, stating she expected an immediate response and a consultant appointment to review her fall and ongoing leg pain, as she felt the ward doctors did not assess or diagnose her.
I explained that her discharge letter indicated no requirement for further follow-up and advised that she should contact her GP to discuss her current symptoms so appropriate treatment or referrals could be arranged. The complainant disagreed, stating she would escalate her concerns to the UHB CEO and other senior leaders to request a consultant review. I clarified that any complaint would still follow the formal process and reiterated that urgent clinical needs should be addressed via her GP as her primary care provider.
The complainant maintained that the hospital should arrange follow-up as she left without a diagnosis and advised she would not follow my recommendation. She confirmed she had seen her GP but did not disclose her symptoms, believing the GP should have known. I encouraged her to inform her GP of her symptoms to enable appropriate care, but she disagreed.
The call concluded with the complainant stating she would not contact her GP and would escalate her concerns to senior executives. I reiterated that her complaint about Ward 16 remains under investigation and again advised that her GP is best placed to address her current symptoms. The complainant thanked me for my time but confirmed she would not follow this advice.

RW - 18.11.2025 - unable to get through to complainant via telephone,  Introduction email sent to complainant with contact details and information on complaint process.
RW - 18.11.2025 - Launched to CDG5Aii - for Ward 16 Medical and Nursing to respond. asked CDG to forward to most appriate medic to assist with response as unable to identify who this was on Icare - Attempted to call complainant to discuss complaint and complaint process. no answer - will attempt again/send email. 
RW - 18.11.2025 - Complaint logged - Rachel to launch and contact complainant to discuss concerns.

column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
Concerns regarding a request for patient to have a psychiatric assessment and a CT scan of her head.
Complainant feels that there has been a lack of communication and lack of joined up working across hospital professionals. 
Concerns regarding an incorrect diagnosis of a dementia; however, following a head CT scan, patient was diagnosed with a brain mass.  
Family requested on numerous occasions to speak to an Oncology specialist to discuss diagnosis, prognosis, and the apparent continued impacts on the pt's type 1 diabetes; however, that was denied.  Family also received conflicting information.
Complainant was not provided with feedback as this was passed by PALS to her estranged brother. 
Complainant also requested that her concerns were escalated from PALS to complaints weeks ago. This was not followed up. Feels the process within PALS is not fit for purpose.

column12: Maternity Urgent Assessment Unit (MUAU) BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21:
The complainant raises serious concerns about care received at Heartlands Hospital following an emergency caesarean section on 12.01.2025, requesting escalation under the Trust's formal complaints procedure. Key issues include:


Post-Operative Neglect & Infection Control
Patient was left on bedding contaminated with blood and surgical debris, causing sores and broken skin. No cleaning or bedding replacement occurred, breaching infection-prevention standards.


Inadequate Pain Management – Breach of Duty of Care
Despite repeated requests for stronger pain relief after major surgery, only paracetamol was provided. No proper pain assessment or escalation occurred until the following day.


Unnecessary Second Surgery & Communication Failures
Imaging suggested blood clots, leading to urgent wound reopening. Later informed no clots were present, with no clear explanation. Raises concerns about imaging accuracy, clinical decision-making, and interdepartmental communication.


Unsafe Discharge & Poor Follow-Up
Patient discharged while still suffering from sores. Health visitor expressed shock and advised urgent return to hospital. Subsequent readmission did not resolve issues before discharge again.


Impact on Health & Wellbeing
Patient experienced avoidable pain, exposure to unhygienic conditions, emotional trauma from unnecessary surgery, and anxiety about maternity and postoperative services.

column21:
Complainant reports serious concerns about the conduct of Luke Richardson, clinician at Solihull Centre, on 20.09.2025. Key issues include:

Failure to provide care for infant in respiratory distress: Six-month-old child presented with visible breathing difficulties. Richardson briefly listened to chest, noted wheeze, but refused further assessment citing no appointments.

Dismissive and negligent behaviour: Declined to check oxygen levels or perform full consultation even after mother offered to wake child. Ignored advice from 111 clinician who deemed symptoms potentially life-threatening.
Refusal to act despite escalating concerns: Reception and Richardson repeatedly dismissed mother's requests and 111's instructions. Suggested child was "just a baby with a cold" and accused mother of "wasting an hour."

Impact and risk: Mother forced to drive 25 minutes to A&E without reassurance, while child remained in distress. Experience described as negligent, condescending, and a breach of duty of care.

column12: Accident & Emergency QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21:
On 20.10.2025, patient attended A&E after GP suspected mini stroke or Bell's palsy due to genetic mutations (Factor V Leiden, MTHFR C677T) and family history. Symptoms included facial and scalp numbness following severe headache.

Dismissal of symptoms: Triage nurse and trainee doctor suggested viral infection; refused scans citing "not enough symptoms."
Lack of diagnosis and treatment: Patient expressed concerns about living alone and risk if condition worsened; still discharged after 9-hour wait.
Miscommunication: Later informed GP that patient "did not attend" despite being escorted out.
Private care and financial impact: Patient sought urgent private neurology consultation; advised immediate MRI and face-to-face review. In Romania, diagnosed with relapsing remitting MS, requiring further investigations and treatment.
Concerns raised: Why was MS not screened? Why were symptoms dismissed? Patient incurred approx. £4,000 costs due to inadequate NHS care.

column12: Ward 513 QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column17: Admissions, Discharges, and Transfers (excluding delayed discharge due to absence of care package)
column21:
Summary of Concerns
I am writing to raise a serious concern regarding the unsafe and failed discharge of Theresa Wolahan (TW), aged 99, from QE Hospital Birmingham on 14 November 2025. The discharge process lacked essential communication, medication provision, and clinical handover, resulting in a medical emergency and reconveyance to hospital. This incident has caused significant risk to the resident's health and safety and raises safeguarding concerns.
 
Chronology of Events
•	13 November 2025 ( 14:17):
A call was received from Nurse Ali on Ward 513 informing us that TW was fit for discharge. Diagnosis was stated as flu, and isolation was required for two further days. A Category 2 pressure ulcer to the sacrum was identified, and we requested hospital to complete the assessment for community district nurse follow-up. Discharge was agreed for Monday 17 November.
•	14 November 2025 (11:00):
A call was received from a nurse on Ward 513 stating transport had been booked and TW was on her way back to the home. This was unexpected as the home had not been informed of discharge today, nor had a handover been completed.
When queried, Nurse Ali admitted he had misread the isolation information and stated isolation had ended yesterday. When our team leader requested a proper handover, Nurse Ali responded that we were "within our rights to complain and to name him" before abruptly ending the call. No handover was provided.
•	Arrival at Home (12:10) :
 Transport staff commented, "Wow, the ward was in a rush for the bed for this one," which reinforced our concerns about the unsafe discharge. Upon arrival, it was identified that TW had been prescribed Furosemide 20mg tablets, which were not sent with her.
•	14 November 2025 (13:40):
TW was seated at the dining table when she began agonal breathing and convulsing. She was placed in the recovery position and 999 was called. Paramedics were under the impression TW was under a further 2 days isolation as per her records they received.  NEWS Score of 8, SATS at 88 with 2L oxygen. TW was reconveyed to hospital. Paramedics confirmed they would raise a safeguarding alert for this failed discharge along with the call handler for the 999.
 
Impact of the failed discharge
•	TW experienced a life-threatening medical emergency shortly after discharge.
•	Lack of medication and clinical handover compromised her safety.
•	Staff were placed under extreme pressure to respond to an avoidable crisis.
•	This incident demonstrates a failure in discharge planning and communication, breaching fundamental standards of care.

column12: Specialty - Rheumatology QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21:
1. Lack of Diagnostic Progress
For over a year, I have experienced severe, disabling symptoms, including:

Joint pain up to 9/10 affecting hands, knees, and feet

Daily swelling, stiffness, and reduced mobility

Near-complete symptom relief in warm climates, with symptoms returning immediately in cold or damp UK conditions

New neurological symptoms, including numbness and tingling extending into my hands, arms, and feet

Despite consistent symptom patterns and multiple consultations, I have not been given a working diagnosis or a clear investigative plan. My concerns have not been adequately addressed.

2. Concerns About Equitable and Consistent Care
I am increasingly concerned that I have not received the same urgency, continuity, or depth of investigation typically afforded to patients presenting with similar symptoms. Over the past year:

My symptoms have been repeatedly minimised despite the substantial impact on my daily functioning.

No proactive or comprehensive investigations have been initiated, even as new and worsening symptoms have developed.

I have had to continually advocate for myself just to obtain basic follow-up or clarification.

Given the well-documented disparities in healthcare outcomes for certain demographic groups, I am concerned that my age and race may be contributing to the lack of urgency and incomplete assessment I have received. My health has deteriorated while I remain without answers, leaving me feeling dismissed, unsupported, and significantly distressed.
