column12: Eden Unit (Bereavement Unit - Maternity) BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21:
The complainant, Laura Fradley-Lowe, attended Heartlands Hospital for a growth scan on 28 October 2025 during her 10th pregnancy. Initially reassured, she was later told there might be fluid on the baby's brain and referred to fetal medicine. At the follow-up on 5 November, she was informed the baby had severe brain abnormalities and would be profoundly disabled, with termination advised.
She underwent a termination procedure on 7 November, followed by induction and delivery of her stillborn son, Bobby, on 10 November. The complainant reports multiple failures, including:

Delayed detection of possible brain abnormality.
Distressing communication and pressure to terminate without full exploration of options.
Poor bereavement care: no bereavement midwife present at birth, inadequate cooling measures, incorrect clothing, and lack of memory-making items.
Prolonged, traumatic induction process with inconsistent plans, lack of food, and minimal support.
Failure to preserve baby's body properly, reducing time for family to spend with him.
Later discovery that the baby might have survived with treatment (e.g., shunt), raising concerns about misdiagnosis and unnecessary termination.

The complainant states these failures caused severe emotional trauma, loss of trust, and lasting mental health impact.

column12: Ward 09 GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column21: I was being moved to Ward 9 with severe pain in my left knee which I couldn't bend at all without hurting. The transfer to the ward bed was very rough and I cried out in pain. The ward sister Ellen mocked me making monkey noises to mimic my screams. I said that the behaviour was rude and offensive but she carried on regardless Below is a copy of the text I sent my wife "Just been moved sorry dumped to Ward 9. The one woman was extremely rude mocking my cries of pain as they just dumped me from bed to bed making actions likening me to a monkey. She then insisted I got back out of bed into a chair to weigh me and then back to bed again all the time making monkey noises and actions. I told her she was bloody rude and I would report her. She said who to?" When my wife visited on the 11th November she asked the sister in charge (Ellen) if she could find out who the person was who brought me onto ward 9. We were told initially that it may have been bank staff. She said she would investigate. The next day sister Ellen accompanied by sister Lailamma asked my wife into a room for a meeting. Sister Ellen then admitted that she, along with two others, had transferred me to the bed. Both Sisters then proceeded to profusely apologise for what they said may have been a'joke' and taken the wrong way. This explanation is farcical and shows a complete misunderstanding of patient care. After speaking to my wife the two Sisters came and again apologised profusely to me. Sister Ellen gave my wife a ticket for free car parking that day.

column21: I was given a surgery date of 18th November 2025 at 7.30am, I was in hospital around 6.30am on the day of surgery I went through all the procedures to get me ready before surgery waited until around 2.40pm/3pm on the day when I was told I would be a day patient and after surgery I would be sent home, the nurse that done the paperwork asked me if I had anyone to look after me at home as I could be a day patient I told her clearly no I do not and have and not made any arrangements to do so as all my family have been told by me that I would be staying in and I have no one to pick me up either, I am very annoyed and displeased about this as I had been told on the letter I received I would be spending 1 night in hospital as I understand this was changed due to the fact that they had no beds available no other reason as I was the last one there and they had an emergency patient come in this is why i was being told this and why I waited so long also because of the emergency that came in I wasn't informed at any stage there is a delay until I asked and the nurse that came to me to explain there was no beds and I need to put in place a plan for next time if I'm a day patient was not sympathetic, or empathetic in any way towards understanding what I was saying, I wouldnt be ok to go home after major surgery as I have no one to look after me I'm totally disgusted and appealed by this, what I want the hospital to do is to do the surgery and have aftercare in the hospital as I do not have any one to look after me and don't feel comfortable as a day patient as this is major life threatening surgery for me and I am struggling daily because it wasn't done properly the first time at Heartlands Hospital this is why I asked to be changed to Queen Elizabeth Hospital and now they are leaving me in doubt and feeling uncomfortable because of the fact that doing the surgery is one part the other most important part is recovery and aftercare also as this is making me mentally stressed and causing me undue anguish as I'm already suffering physically the last thing I need is more tension and stress and hope you can remedy this issue as soon as possible. Much Appreciated

column12: Accident & Emergency BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21: I am writing to raise a formal complaint regarding the conduct and professionalism of a doctor who saw myself and my child at your NHS hospital today. I am extremely concerned by the way we were spoken to and the overall attitude displayed during the consultation. From the beginning of the appointment, the doctor did not introduce herself, acknowledge us properly, or make any effort to create a safe or respectful environment. Her manner was rude, dismissive, and patronising throughout the consultation. When I began explaining my child's symptoms and the concerns I had—based on what we had observed at home—she interrupted me and sarcastically asked whether I was a health professional. When I replied that I was not, she responded again in a sarcastic tone: "Oh, so you just read up then." This was completely unnecessary, unprofessional, and made me feel belittled for simply trying to provide relevant information to support an accurate assessment of my child. I had brought a urine sample with me, as I believed it might assist in identifying the cause of my child's symptoms. The doctor pushed it away with a hand gesture and said, "I don't understand why you have brought that," showing no interest in considering any information I provided. I also explained that my child had been in significant pain the day before and had struggled to walk. In response, the doctor instructed my child to stand up and jump. My child complied only because they were made to feel embarrassed and uncomfortable, not because they were pain-free. During the brief examination, the doctor placed a pulse oximeter on my child's finger but did not look at or record the readings. She simply left it on and walked away, and I eventually had to remove it myself. Although my child was not showing many symptoms at the time of the appointment, I believe it is important to seek medical attention when there are concerns about something potentially serious, such as a grumbling appendix. I attended the hospital purely to raise my concerns and ensure my child was safe. Instead of being listened to, I was completely dismissed. Overall, I left the appointment feeling unheard, disrespected, and deeply concerned about the lack of care and attention shown toward both myself and my child. This experience has undermined our confidence in the care we should be able to expect from NHS staff. I request that this matter be investigated and that appropriate steps are taken to address the doctor's behaviour. I would also like confirmation that feedback will be used to prevent similar experiences for other patients in the future. Thank you for your attention. I look forward to your response
column22: 24.11.25 ST - launched to SmartCare Ellie Daniels/Andrea Jones ED OPS/GM
column23: 21/11/25 - RL - Complaint launched to handler (ST).

column12: Accident & Emergency BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21: I went into A&E on the 8th of November regarding a health concern. I had been referred by 111 to go to the hospital. My boyfriend, who does not live with me, went to A&E for his own health conditions. We both bumped into each other in A&E. During this period of time, I had found out that a registered nurse in A&E named Noreen had broken confidentiality and disclosed my personal notes with another patient without my consent and had given her opinions on my relationship with my boyfriend. She questioned my boyfriend about a crash that was in my notes and had revealed and discussed my notes with him when I was not present or aware of this. My boyfriend did not know about the crash and has now been revealed without my permission or consent. Noreen, the nurse, had also questioned my relationship with my boyfriend, and she advised him to "block me" and "remove me from his life". She also stated to my boyfriend that "I am not a good woman and that he should leave me"; she was also asking him whether I should be told to leave the hospital, and she had taken his belongings into a private room. I was not aware of this at the time, and the comments that Noreen made resulted in my boyfriend having a panic attack as she was giving her opinions on me. She also questioned him about whether he loves me, and she also discussed my notes with my boyfriend, which he did not know about from me. She had discussed with him that I had been in and out of the hospital, I had discharged myself and had mentioned the crash. I kept the car crash that I experienced on a down low and kept it to myself due to the mental trauma and effect it had upon me, and now he has knowledge of this, which I am not happy about.

column12: Ward 22 (MAU) BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21: On Monday 22/9/25 my Mother was referred via her GP to the medical assessment unit at Heartlands hospital for a suspected PE. This was due to worsening symptoms of thoracic pain, shortness of breath on minimal exertion and an abnormal d-dimer blood test and Chest X-ray showing signs of pulmonary oedema and with a constant dry cough. On this evening she was assessed, given anticoagulant medication and advised to return the next day for a CT scan with contrast in the day assessment unit to investigate any possible PE. This scan was completed on the morning of the 23/9/25 and we were seen by a senior consultant radiologist (I am unsure of his name) whom advised there was no PE and he advised her symptoms where musculoskeletal - something which at the time both myself (a senior advanced MSK physiotherapist of nearly 13 years) and her GP disputed as her symptoms were non-mechanical in nature. This ended our contact with this clinician and we had not heard from him or aware of his details until last Friday 14/11/25 where by during this time my mothers symptoms of shortness of breath, thoracic pain and cough had deteriorated, she had a further chest x-ray whereby a greater level of plural effusion was found and subsequently via an A&E admission was referred for a second CT scan on the cancer 2 week urgent care pathway. This scan was completed on 30/10 and an urgent referral was sent to the chest clinic. Worsening symptoms led to a second A&E referral whereby 3.5 litres of fluid was found on the lung with a tumor noted on the lung - at the chest clinic app on 14/11 the senior respiratory consultant advised that the cancer was present on the first CT scan completed in the day ax unit at Heartlands and this was not picked up by the reviewing consultant on the morning of the 23/9. We have been advised there is already an internal investigation being started via Ben Sutton at the QE however my question is simply - why did a senior radiology consultant not review my mothers scan fully and consider looking for a cancerous tumour in the lung with reported symptoms of shortness of breath, thoracic chest pain, a persistent cough with an abnormal d-dimer bloods test and signs of pleural effusion on an x-ray. This cancer diagnosis has been missed for a further 6 weeks - this has led to 2 further A&E admissions, loss of diagnosis time and access to treatment earlier and more stress for my mum and all of us as a family. We would like to query medical negligence from the reviewing clinician at Heartlands hospital.

column12: Accident & Emergency BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21: I went into A&E following advice from the NHS 111 service. A big concern was symptoms I had and the fact I was pregnant. I was clearly very anxious and worried as I was in my first trimester and showing some signs of miscarriage. After waiting I was called through to have observations taken and the nurse said the hospital needed to do a urine sample to check my pregnancy. After 8 hours of sitting in the waiting room waiting to see a doctor, anxious to know what what going on and worrying about my pregnancy, I decided to go and ask a member of staff to check sample results and when I was likely to see a doctor. After asking, she checked on the system and very casually said that my pregnancy test was now negative. In that moment it was clear I was having a miscarriage, but to be told this information in a room full of people, with no sensitivity or compassion whatsoever made it so much worse to hear. And why I was not told this result after my urine was checked is disgraceful (I was waiting 8hours before I went and asked, I wonder how long it would have taken had I not have asked). I am appalled at the service and how I was just left sitting there for so long, worrying and wondering about the fate of my pregnancy, based on the symptoms that sent me to the department. The way the news was given to me has made this so much harder as well, I am really let down by the service today.

column8: Acute and Short Stay Medicine QEH
column12: Harborne Ward QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21: Mrs Parkes was widowed in Oct 2024 and lived alone. She was fit, had an allotment, attended dancing lessons and is a driver. On Monday 15 Sept Mrs Parkes had a fall at home in garden. She waited 4 hours for an ambulance and then 6 hours outside A&E. Once admitted to AMU diagnosed with broken wrist and broken pubic bones. Treated on that ward until Thursday 16 Sept at 08.00. Elizabeth was then transported by wheelchair to Harborne Ward, Heritage Building. I had spoken to Elizabeth on the day before, phoned again on the Thursday afternoon when she told me she had been sitting on a chair on the ward since 8 am waiting for a bed. I visited her at about 6 pm to find she was still in the chair (now for 10 hours). She was very tearful. The chair was by the entrance to a very busy bay , staff in and out. Elizabeth had requested another chair to rest her injured leg. She also asked for a pillow so she could rest her head on a nearby table. Doctor had told her to stand up once an hour. No help from staff to do that. I saw nurse at station who informed me that Matron was well aware of situation, AMU needed bed (understandable). I was astounded by what I saw. I was asked to leave ward at 7 pm but refused so that I could make sure she was in a bed. Finally at 8 pm Elizabeth was given a bed (12 hours in that chair). At 8pm I was shouted by a nurse to go home just after Liz got into the bed. During her time on the ward she was given little or no help to wash. She became dehydrated and was hallucinating. I kept her next of kin, brother Robert (who lives 200 miles away in Kent), informed. Eventually discharged home with support because of injuries and accessing upstairs bathroom. Brother Robert did visit from Kent on a number of occasions. We were horrified that Elizabeth sat in a chair for 12 hours. Elizabeth herself was very grateful for the care given by most of the staff on the ward although there were a couple of occasions when she was shouted at for walking to the toilet when told to walk more by a doctor. Overall it was a distressing stay in Harborne ward. I saw a notice on door to bay which said a member of staff should be present in bay at all times. This did not happen.

column12: Ward 06 BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21: During my grandmother's stay on ward 6 we had a number of issues. The neglect of care, lack of compassion, bedside manner and the non adherence to the trust values was portrayed throughout my grand mothers stay. She also had an unsafe discharge which resulted her in becoming critically unwell 48hrs later. There was unclear and unconsistent communication throughout her admission. On one occassion she had deteriorated on the night, her next of kin was not updated or contacted about a change in her condition. My grandad was very upset the next morming when he came in to see her like this. She was a high risk falls patient due to her low sodium and confusion. She had a fall in the bathroom where she was unattended and unassisted. She had multiple scans but we were not told about the results until a few days later despite asking multiple times. Regular pain relief was not given to her despite her asking, she felt ignored due to her language barrier. She developed a blood stream infection, staphylococcus aureus. This was secondary to the phelebitis on her left arm where she had a cannula, the medical team or nursing staff did not apologise about this incident. This extended her stay in hospital. Nursing staff came to administer my grandmother's IV medication, they sometimes had no intention of flushing the cannula but just to attach the medication. Gloves were not worn when giving IV medication. She had a cannula in her hand for more than 72hrs, the cannula was inserted on 17/10/25 and was still being used all the way up until the 22/10/25 for her antbiotics. During morning ward round it was made clear that she needed IV fluids and steriods, due to her poor kidney function these were not given till late afternoon. There was a lack of unprofessionalism and communication from senior members of staff. We wanted to speak to the ward manager about issues that had occured during my grandmother's admission, however this never happened when we requested. The ward manager was also very rude and unprofessional with an encounter she had with my mother about some water spilled on the floor by my grandmother's bedspace. She made it seemed that it was her fault the water was on the floor. We escalated my grandmother's work of breathing on multiple occassions and explained this was not normal for her. However, we were dismissed and was told that this is normal for a "cardiac patient". The day of discharge she had a low grade temperature of 37.9, but to the nursing staff it seemed this was not enough for it to be a "temperature spike". 48hrs later my grandmother was taken to QE where she was in respiratory acidosis and multiple organ failure.

column8: Lower GI Surgery (incl General Surgery Electives) QEH
column12: Ward 621/SAU QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column18: Delay or failure to undertake scan/x-ray, etc.
column21:
1. Why was an ultrasound scan not arranged immediately, when I was presenting such alarming symptoms upon arriving at A&E? Why was there no effective escalation procedure to ensure timely investigation and transfer in a possible medical emergency, where an organ could have been at risk? Why did I have to wait until Friday (daytime) for a scan? 

2. Why the commitment regarding when my scan would take place on Thursday was not fulfilled, despite my symptoms persisting and the doctor acknowledging that my pain could be related to my ovary? I am appalled that a major reproductive organ with two key functions (hormone production and fertility) was identified as being at risk, yet wasn't investigated promptly. Ovarian torsion is a medical emergency.

3. Why my transfer to the Birminghan Women's Hospital was delayed for over six hours, despite multiple hospital porters affirming that it would have been possible to wheel me across to the Birmingham Women's Hospital, and get me there sooner in spite of ambulance availability? My ultrasound scan had shown an abnormally enlarged right ovary which did not demonstrate any bloodflow within it, suggesting ovarian torsion, yet l wasn't urgently transferred to a ward/department/hospital who could operate on me and carry out organ-saving surgery. 

4. Why a copy of my ultrasound scan was not given to me to take to the Birmingham Women's Hospital? This caused further delay to my diagnosis and treatment. My ovary, a major reproductive organ, had already been identified as being at risk by the time I was being transferred to the Birmingham Women's Hospital. 

5. What measures the Trust will put in place to ensure that such failings don't occur again for patients presenting with similar symptoms?

column21: Inadequate care provided by the A&E team on Friday 21st November 2025, my partner Samuel Ward D.O.B 05/08/1993 went to A&E with worsening symptoms, when explaining about having new and worse fatigue and normally being able to work hard he was told we all work hard, that there was no male doctors to examine him so she could only have a look after looking she told Samuel its just swollen and to go home and finish the course of antibiotics. Samuel suffered due to this his swelling got 100 times worse yet he was afraid to return to A&E because he didn't want to waste anyone's time thinking it was not a medical emergency because of what the clinician had said to him. Samuel is now on a surgical ward in the QE they are as confused as we are as to why he was sent away when the issue is clearly a medical emergency.

column12: Breast Care QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column18: Delay or failure to undertake scan/x-ray, etc.
column21:
I have concerns that some of the statements made in the review are 
inaccurate. 
1.	Yasmin did not delay treatment because of the pain she was experiencing. No treatment was offered to Yasmin. 
2. A bone density scan was only offered l, after Yasmin questioned 
why she Was experiencing such pain and her Daughter Jade insisting 
her Mother have a bone density scan in the hope of finding out 
why Yasmin was in extreme Pain.  
3. I was present with Yasmin when we saw the Cancer Nurse regarding
What medication Yasmin would be required to take prior to the start of 
Her Chemotherapy, and I requested that Yasmin needed to see either her
own Consultant or a Dr off the Cancer ward as I was concerned that Yasmin
now had Yellow Jaundice and unexplained bruises on her lower back.
I can assure you we were told to make an appointment to see Yasmin's own 
GP. It was only because at this point I insisted the Nurse go and fetch
someone to assess Yasmin as I would not be taking my sister 
anywhere explaining that Yasmin's GP was not a Cancer specialist. The Nurse relented and bought in Dr Riaz. It was after Dr Riaz examined Yasmin that my sister was admitted Into the Queen Elizabeth Hospital.

column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21: I have been referred by 999 ambulance service to go A&E as soon as possible. I have been there because got vaginal bleeding with large blood clots passing, difficulty in breathing and chest pain when breathing. They took my urine sample, blood sample and also ecg. After long 4 hours wait dr. Called me. He asked me what happened. I told him about the situation abd my test sample. He said there's is nothing updating on your system. And also they didn't send any sample to lab. Like really. Why then m i supposed to give sample and long wait. What's the point. He said go to your gp but gp is the same they dont give me appointment. M worrying about my health and also got anemia, blood and iron deficiency before. How could these guys be irresponsible. I need proper health treatment. But these guys doesn't care what m going through. He just prescribed me old medication.

column12: Accident & Emergency GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
Patient's Daughter emailed ICB re care and treatment by GHH and GP, in particular the issues for GHH are:
1.  Why was Patient discharged from A&E in August 2025, without any follow-up information, after her TIA diagnosis?
2.  Why was the letter dated 26th August 2025, recommending an urgent cancer referral, only received by the family on 23rd September 2025?
3.  Why did Good Hope Hospital not make any direct contact with the family
regarding the urgent referral recommendation?
4.  What impact might the month-long delay in care and diagnosis have on  Patient's health?
5.   Could this delay have affected the timeliness and effectiveness of potential cancer treatment?
6.  Why did the medical secretaries at GHH not offer a sincere apology or clear explanation when contacted?

column12: Ward 24 BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
How come after countless visits to hospital and being dismissed did medical professionals not find a blood clot?
Why wasn't an MRI scan completed?
My mom was left without oxygen in MAU what will be done about this, as there was a distinct lack of care in her last few days?
Why did no one prepare us? 
Why did a doctor say that she is not dying on the Saturday only for her to die on the Monday?
Why did the hospital choose such an aggressive treatment plan and neglect her throughout?
She was still under the care of the haematology doctor, where was she in the final days?
Why did so many medical professionals let her progressively get worse?
If it was spotted at her first hospital visit post surgery could she still be here now?
Why during her treatment for breast cancer was she scrapped and did have a mastectomy immediately?
Why was she not in the intensive care unit?
Why were doctors convinced it was a lung infection?
Why was she constantly sent home with depression and antibiotics when she was clearly so unwell?
Why in her latest appointment with oncology where my dad told them she couldn't wipe the board did they dismiss her and send her home?
If the treatment killed her why was she not monitored closer and why were they trying to get her to have more?
My mom went down hill post surgery in January, why was a thorough investigation not completed for a blood clot?
The damage was already done by the time she ended up in hospital, why wasn't it spotted sooner? We were stole of the chance to say good bye.
Why did no one prepare us? 
Why did the consultant on the 1st June state that after looking at the scans for an hour that he was confident it was an infection that could be treated and that we should see an improvement in 5 days for her to die on the 2nd?

column8: Stroke (incl OPD for all Sites) QEH
column12: Ward 514 QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
When I got to the QE by ambulance I was taken straight through for a CT scan and observations. They struggled to get the dye in through my canula for the scan as it was very very painful when they did and nothing was getting through, this had to be taken out and redone as apparently the one that was in hadn't been put in as it should of and the dye was being blocked from getting through to my veins hence why it was so painful when they tried to do so. 
I was then left on a bed in the Resus area for several hours as there was no bed available on a ward for me, I complained on many occasions that the noise and the bright lights were making me become very agitated, restless, upset and the pain in my neck was becoming very severe. I was struggling with the pain in my eyes and head which the noise and bright lights was not helping, but was told there was nothing they could do or move me and had to stay where I was. I was unable to have the pain relief I needed incase of a stroke also. I was informed that I had signs of a stroke which was reported as expressive aphasia and that I had also been tested positive for covid which I was not aware of.  
I was finally put on to the stroke ward the following morning and found myself needing to urinate more than usual, almost every 1.5-2 hours. I stayed at the QE for 2 days and was then taken back to the ROH on the 23rd January

column12: Ward 23 GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column18: Delay or failure in treatment/procedure/clinical assessment
column21:
Mum was taken by ambulance to Good Hope in the early hours of Friday 28th Nov with a suspected cardiac issue. She remained in that ambulance for 5 hours. She was considerably unwell and uncomfortable. The ambulance crew were Fran and Callum. I think that it was ambulance number 4275. Issues:

 

Bloods to check for a heart attack were not taken despite persistent efforts by Fran for some time. When this was finally done, Fran was initially given an incorrect result reading of circa 20. She felt that Mum was too unwell for this to be accurate and repeatedly took the heart rate scans back into A&E to try and get help. It transpired that she was given the wrong readings and the actual rate was circa 770 and escalating (this peaked at 15,000 – and was deemed to be a significant heart attack). No hospital care was given to Mum despite Fran's repeated calls to action.
Fran reported that there were 2 free bays in A&E and had to chase the medic in charge to notice this and actually admit Mum. We finally went into Resus after 10am ish
Based on the fact that Mum is 89, was clearly in trouble, has dementia and had a history of heart attacks, we were rather left to it for much of the morning. The A&E doctor (Hind) took history but not much more was done. We were moved to Majors after lunch and it was suggested that a bed on Ward 23 Cardio (the site of all of the issues last time as per the complaint) had happened.
Admitting Mum has challenges for her due to her dementia – she won't eat and gets terribly upset whilst in hospital. My elderly father and I took shifts to cover her as much as possible. We were promised follow up bloods and monitoring (the whole point of admitting her) but my father had to chase this on the ward at 8pm that night as no one had done anything.
When the Cardio consultant did finally arrive on ward rounds – circa 5pm on Saturday 29th – he was arguing with my elderly father that he wanted to admit Mum to Heartlands for an 'intervention'. She does not want this and we – with full power of attorney for her – do not think this in her best interests either. We had a letter from our private consultant – the Cardio clinical lead for your area, Professor Leyva and My Khan (cardio surgeon at UHB) suggesting that an intervention was very high risk and voting against this. When faced with a lack of meek compliance from us, the cardio consultant rather lost interest in  my Mum.
My father saw him again for ward rounds the next day and this was played out again – unhelpfully.
I have sat with my Mum for hours across the last 4 days. No nursing staff have one in all that time checked that she is eating and drinking – had we not been there, she would have been significantly dehydrated. We waited 5 hours yesterday for them to find meds and the discharge letter. All of the nursing staff on Ward 23 seem to sit and chat rather than check in on patients. I repeatedly asked for paracetamol for her pain – this took on average 1.5 hours to arrive.

column12: Specialty - Acute and Short Stay Medicine QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column17: Admissions, Discharges, and Transfers (excluding delayed discharge due to absence of care package)
column21:
DEATH IN HOSPITAL
On 16th October, Natasha absconded from West 1 Ward at UHB while suffering from a
suspected blood clot.
The police were called but left her at an unsafe address, despite professionals knowing that
the resident had a history of violence, coercive control, and financial abuse towards her.
On 17th October, UHB sent an ambulance to collect her, but she was again left at the
property, even though she had not received any medication and was severely unwell.
• Natasha's social worker and safeguarding leads had previously applied a MARAC for her
protection, but it was never renewed after it lapsed — despite repeated family requests.
Natasha was subject to over 50 safeguarding referrals across multiple agencies, yet none
resulted in sustained protection
Communication/Attitude of Staff

column12: Specialty - Ear Nose Throat (ENT) UHB (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21:
1.	Failure to adequately correct the left nostril deviation and scarring in the original 2018 operation, despite these issues being raised at the time.
2.	Poor record keeping and transparency around the September 2021 psychiatric assessment with Dr Uttam Shiralka, including the apparent absence of any report in my GP record and the fact I have never been provided with an outcome.
3.	The late cancellation of my revision surgery booked for 30 September 2025, after pre assessment and significant personal/work disruption, with no clear rescheduling plan.
4.	The subsequent imposition of a requirement for a BDD specialist psychiatric letter (as set out in the 4 November 2025 email from Ms Brookes Reid) that is, in practice, extremely hard to meet given the scarcity of such specialists and the complexity of referral routes.
5.	The way my reasonable attempts to confirm, clarify and preserve my long awaited surgery date have been interpreted as "alarming" and used to justify further psychiatric hurdles instead of honest, direct communication about risks and options.
6.	The overall pattern of poor communication, shifting criteria, and delay, which has prolonged my distress, worsened my ADHD related difficulties and left my original surgical problems unresolved seven years on.

column12: Specialty - Older People's Services (incl OPAL) BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21:
DEATH IN HOSPITAL - 18/02/2025
On Friday 14th February, patient had a CT scan that showed he had Metastatic Lung Cancer that had spread to his liver. This news was a huge shock to family and would've been devastating news to patient. 
Over the past 18 months, patient had had numerous blood tests and x-rays for various things. He had also been seen by many Doctors at the GP surgery and at hospital appointments.
Metastatic Cancer is Stage 4 Cancer so not something that suddenly appears. Family want to know if anything was missed during any consultation with a GP or a Doctor at any hospital appointment or from any of the blood tests and x-rays that patient had. 
Family have many questions but main question is that why the cancer was not picked up sooner, considering the amount of medical appointments patient had.

column12: Kings Norton Dialysis Unit OFFSITE (Offsite/ Other Sites)
column18: Injury sustained during treatment or operation
column21: During Dialysis session, a nurse attempted to access patient vascular site more than four times, despite patient repeatedly stating that the attempts were causing him significant pain. Patient made it clear that the procedure was hurting him, yet the attempts continued. This is especially concerning because his consultant had clearly advised that this access site should not be used for six weeks. At the time of the incident, only three weeks had passed. The decision to proceed against medical instructions put patient at unnecessary risk. The result of this was not only severe distress for patient (who has only recently come out of a two week stay at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital), but also significant physical trauma. His arm became extensively bruised, black and blue, This experience has left patient feeling anxious and fearful about future dialysis sessions using the new vascular site, and complainant is extremely concerned about both the physical and emotional impact this has caused.

column12: Specialty - Diabetes QEH (Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham)
column21:
I am a type 1 diabetic under the care of the diabetes team at the QE Birmingham. 
In February this year I was moved onto the Medtronic pump under the advice of the hospital to help improve my diabetic control. 
The improvement was literally over night and after a few days the pump was put into "smartguard" mode which to full control of my diabetic control. Within a matter of weeks my hba1c went from 75 down to 55. 
In May this year I attended the eye clinic at the QE as I suffer with severe diabetic retinopathy. I was told that my eyes were looking very good but they did warn me that a sudden improvement in my blood sugars could lead to complications. I did not fully understand what they meant but assumed that the diabetic team had this in hand and were aware of any complications. 
On the 22nd October I woke up and I had lost all sight in my right eye due to a diabetic haemorrhage. 
I am now 7 weeks down the line with no improvement in my sight. I am off work, I am unable to drive, to exercise at the gym, it is impacting on every aspect of my life. I am suffering from daily Headaches and nausea. My depression and anxiety have returned, I have missed important meetings and targets at work. I am missing out on social events and celebrations for my wife's 60th birthday. I cannot go out at night, I cannot judge simple distances even eating a meal is not a nice experience due to blurred vision
I need answers as to why every healthcare professional I have seen since the haemorrhage has said this is a common side effect of rapid improvement in diabetic control and yet, I was never told this by the team and more importantly, there was no attempt to put in place a more gradual reduction in target blood sugars which could have been done so easily via the pump. The target blood sugar could have been gradually reduced over 3,6,9 or 12 months but there was no attempt to mitigate this terrible side effect. 
I don't know if I will get my sight back or if indeed my other eye could also still be in danger. 
Since the 22nd I have had numerous injections in my eye and laser treatment.

•	incurred costs for parking, fuel, KT tape, and a purchased my own wrist support
•	spent hours at multiple unnecessary appointments across two hospitals (7 appointments) 
•	now face delayed healing that should have occurred in 4–6 weeks if diagnosed early. Healing process commenced from splint provided on 19th Nov (original injury date 29th Sept)

column8: Acute and Short Stay Medicine BHH
column12: Same Day Emergency Care (SDEC) BHH (Heartlands Hospital Site)
column21:
I am writing to formally raise serious concerns regarding the content and conduct surrounding my recent medical experience report authored by Dr Awais Raees and E Hayton.

I am requesting the immediate removal of this report from my medical records due to factual inaccuracies, inappropriate clinical conclusions, and what I believe to be discriminatory practice rooted in age and gender based bias and stereotyping.

I will also be formally raising this matter with my local Member of Parliament, Jess Phillips MP, whom I will be copying into this correspondence. As a longstanding and prominent advocate for women's rights and for addressing gender based inequality within public services, I believe it is appropriate that she is made aware of my experience and the concerns it raises regarding the treatment of women within clinical settings. This case reflects wider and well documented patterns of gender bias and dismissal of women's symptoms in healthcare, and I consider it a matter of public interest as well as personal significance that it is scrutinised appropriately.

On Saturday 13 December, I attended the Same Day Emergency Care clinic at Heartlands Hospital following a referral from my GP. This referral was made due to ongoing abdominal and neuropathic pain, vomiting, unstable blood glucose levels, and an unintentional weight loss of five kilograms within one month, alongside other concerning symptoms. I have a long standing diagnosis of Type 1 diabetes with unstable glycemic control and albuminuria, which was highly relevant to my presentation and clinical risk.

During this attendance, I was seen by two male doctors with no family or chaperone present. Throughout the consultation, I was repeatedly interrupted while attempting to explain my symptoms. My concerns were dismissed, and I was informed that I was depressed, despite not presenting with symptoms suggestive of depression or any other mental health condition. This conclusion appeared to have been reached without appropriate clinical assessment, exploration, or differential consideration. I am concerned that this judgement was influenced by my presentation as a young woman experiencing pain, rather than by an evidence based evaluation of my symptoms. I question whether a previously healthy, professionally active male patient experiencing two months of progressive, debilitating pain resulting in functional impairment and confinement to bed would have been so readily assigned a psychiatric explanation in the absence of supporting evidence.

My symptoms were not adequately explored, and I do not believe I was listened to in a meaningful or professional manner. Notably, my blood glucose records were not reviewed, despite clear evidence of instability reported by my GP and on my glucose monitor. Neuropathic pain, vomiting, and profound fatigue were described as general and non specific symptoms and attributed to depression, rather than being appropriately considered in the context of my long term diabetes and potential medical complications.
The discharge report contains multiple factual inaccuracies. It states that I demonstrated willingness to engage with mental health services, which is categorically untrue and was never expressed by me. In addition, the report records an incorrect weight. I was not weighed during this attendance, yet the report lists me as being four kilograms heavier than my current weight. This appears to be a historical value and therefore fails to acknowledge my rapid and clinically significant recent weight loss.

I do not agree with the mental health assessment documented in this report and strongly refute its validity. The conclusion was reached following a brief and dismissive interaction, without adequate history taking, investigation, or consideration of my existing medical conditions or any medical conditions that may not be identified through CT scans and repeats of the same basic blood tests. I have been formally diagnosed with elevated microalbumin, high resting heart rate, gallbladder wall thickening and polyps - all empirical and verifiable evidence reported at Heartlands Hospital and not features of the diagnostic criteria for depression. I believe this represents unconscious bias and discriminatory practice.

In this regard, I wish to explicitly reference the General Medical Council's guidance set out in Good Medical Practice. This guidance is clear that doctors must treat patients as individuals, listen carefully to their accounts, and avoid making assumptions or clinical judgements based on personal characteristics such as gender. It also makes clear that stereotyping and unconscious bias can undermine safe and effective care and compromise clinical decision making - especially in persistent physical symptoms. I am concerned that these standards were not upheld in my case.

I would also like to clarify my professional background, as it directly informs my perspective. I am a qualified secondary and college level educator who works closely with vulnerable young people, including students with Education Health and Care Plans and those with complex mental health needs. Through my professional role, I have a strong understanding of mental health conditions and their impact, and I do not attach stigma, shame, or dismissal to mental health diagnoses. My concern is not with mental health being considered where clinically appropriate, but with the timing, framing, and weighting of such conclusions in a case involving unresolved physical symptoms and objective findings.

Following the consultation, I was left waiting for a further four hours with a cannula still in situ and without any pain relief. I was not informed that I had been discharged. It was only after I approached a nurse myself that I was told I should have been sent home several hours earlier.

This type of bias has serious implications for patient safety and trust in medical care. Inaccurate and prejudicial documentation of this nature risks undermining future clinical assessments and delaying appropriate diagnosis and treatment. I wish to emphasise that I have only attended hospital services following GP advice and through the appropriate referral pathways.

column12: Ward 05 GHH (Good Hope Hospital Site)
column21:
Patient emailed re traumatic maternity care (during and post-birth and readmission) at GHH, including the following concerns:
Significant delays during induction and labour, including limited medical review despite severe back pain, prolonged rupture of membranes (over 36 hours), and late identification of malposition, resulting in emergency caesarean section and infection. Inconsistent post-caesarean ward care, including inappropriate ward allocation, distressing communication, delayed discharge due to medication issues, and lack of dignity during recovery.
Patient subsequently suffered from post natal depression and suicidal thoughts.

column21: We were told that this was an emergency but then had to wait several days for the QE to find Michael a bed. Every day we were waiting for news on when Michael would be moved which was very stressful especially as Michael was wasting away and it was also affecting his mental health. In the end I insisted on a meeting with the surgeon to find out exactly when this was going to happen and on 23 September (11 days after the first operation) Michael was moved to the QE.
